projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: OR, A Pleasant Grove FOR THEIR WITS TO WALK IN.
With their Addition, Multiplication, and Division.
LONDON, Printed by M: Simmons, in Aldersgate-Street. 1654.
WITT'S RECREATIONS refined Augmented, with Ingenious CONCEITES for the wittie, And Merrie Medicines for the Melancholie.
Printed by M.S. sould by Edw: Archer in Little Brittain. 1654.

div.head: Ad Lectorem.
div.l: THis little Book is like a furnishe Feast;
And hath a dish, I hope, to please each guest.
Here thou may'st find some good and solid fare;
Perhaps sh • rp sawces take thee most; if so,
I have Cooke for thee some sharp sawces too;
But if thy squemish stomack can like none,
No body hinders thee, thou may'st be gone.

div.head: The Stationer to the Reader.
div.l: IF new, or old wit, please the Reader best,
I've hope, each man of wit, will be our Guest
The new, was fram'd to humour some mens tast▪
Which if they like not, they may carve the last▪
Each dish hath sawce belongs to't; and you wil •
By your dislike, censure the Authors skill;
Yet if you cannot speake well of it, spare
To utter your dislike, that the like snare
May entrap o • hers; so the Booke may be
Sold, though not lik'd▪ by a neat fallacie:
That's all I aske, yet 'twill your goodness raise,
If as I gaine your coyne, he may your praise.

div.head: 1. To the Reader.
div.l: EXcuse mee Reader, though I now and than,
In some light lines, doe shew my selfe a man;
Nor be so sowre, some wanton words to blame,
They are the language of an Epigramme.

div.head: 2. On Battus.
div.l: Battus doth brag he hath a world of Books,
His Studies maw holds more then well it may,
But seld' or never, he upon them looks,
And yet he looks upon them every day.
He looks upon their outside, but within
He never looks, nor never will begin.

div.head: 3. On Prue.
div.l: Prues nose hangs down so low, one would suppose
When ere she gapes, that Prue would eat her nose.

div.head: 4. To Gripe.
div.l: Gripe keeps his coyn well, and his heaps are great,
For which he seems wise in his own conceit;
Be not deceiv'd Gripe, for ought I can see,
Thy bags in this sense are as wise as thee.

div.head: 5. On Man and Woman.
div.l: When man and Woman dyes, as Poets sung,
His heart's the last that stirs, of hers the tongue.

div.head: 6. On Womans will.
div.l: How dearly doth the honest husband buy
His wives defect of will when she doth dy?
Better in death by will to let her give,
Then let her have her will while she doth live.

div.head: 7. Spangle the spruce Gal:
div.l: Spruce Spangle's like to a Cynamon Tree;
His outside is of much more worth then he.

div.head: 8. Chaerilus.
div.l: Eat Toste and Oyle, eat supple herbs and loos,
For thou look'st wondrous costive Chaerilus.

div.head: 9. In Paulum.
div.l: By lawfull Mart, and by unlawfull stealth,
P • ulus from th'Ocean hath deriv'd much wealth:
But on the Land, a little gulfe there is,
Wherein he drowneth all that wealth of his.

div.head: 10. Vestitus peritus.
div.l: Clitus goes oft time clad in Suits of Scarlet,
That els no colour had to play the Varlet.

div.head: 11. Of Poetus.
div.l: Poetus with fine Sonnets painted forth
This and that foul Ladies beauties worth:
He shews small wit therein, and for his pains,
Why, what needs Poets paint them, O sweet Elves!
When Ladies paint their beauties best themselves.

div.head: 12. Of Shift the Sharker.
div.l: Shift swears he keeps none but good company,
For, though th'are such as he did never see,
Worse then himselfe he's sure they cannot be.

div.head: 13. On an Vpstart.
div.l: Pray wrong not (late coyn'd) give the man his right,
He's made a Gentleman although no Knight,
For now 'tis cloaths the Gentleman doth make,
Men from gay cloaths their pedegrees doe take;
But wot you what's the arms to such mens house?
Why this—hands chancing of a Rampant Louse.

div.head: 14. Volens Nolens.
div.l: Will with provisio wills you testifie,
Has made his will, but hath no will to die.

div.head: 15. Ad Clodium.
div.l: Wit, once thou said'st was worth thy weight in gold,
Though now't be common for a trifle sold;
It dearer seems to thee that get'st not any,
(When thou shouldst use it) for thy love or money.

div.head: 16. In Getam.
div.l: Geta from wooll and weaving first began,
Swelling and swelling to a Gentleman;
When he was Gentleman and bravely dight,
He left not swelling till he was a Knight:
At last (forgetting what he was at first)
He sweld to be a Lord, and then he burst.

div.head: 17. To Emson.
div.l: Emson thou once in Dutch wouldst court a wench,
But to thy cost she answered thee in French.

div.head: 18. In Fimum.
div.l: Fimus is Coach'd, and for his farther grace
Troth I should tel him, the poor coach hath wrong
And that a Cart would serve to carry dung.

div.head: 19. In Flaccum.
div.l: The false knave Flaccus once a bribe I gave;
The more fool I, to bribe so false a knave:
But he gave back my bribe, the more fool he,
That for my folly did not cousen me.

div.head: 20. Of Womens naked breasts.
div.l: In open shop • flyes often blow that flesh,
Which in close safe • might be kept longer fresh.
They but invite flesh-flyes, whose full spread pap •
Like road wayes lie between their lips and laps.

div.head: 21. On Morcho.
div.l: Morcho for haste was married in the night,
What needed day? his fair young wife is light.

div.head: 22. On a Bragadocio.
div.l: Don Lollus brags, he comes from Noble blood,
Drawn down from Brutus line; 'tis very good,
If this praise-worthy be, each Flea may then,
Boast of his blood more then som Gentlemen.

div.head: 23. Edens vomens.
div.l: Cacus that sups so duly at the Rose,
Casts up the reckning truly ere he goes.

div.head: 24. On a Pumpe stopt with stones.
div.l: M. I'le cut it down, I swear by this same hand,
If 'twill not run, it shall no longer stand.
R. Pray Sir be patient, let your Pump alone,
How can it water make when't hath the stone?
Yet did he wisely when he did it fell.
For in so doing he did make it well.

div.head: 25. Of Prittle-prattle.
div.l: Though th'danger be not great, of all tame cattle,
Yet the most troublesome is Prittle-prattle.

div.head: 26. In Aulum.
div.l: Thou still art muttring Aulus in mine ear,
Love me and love my Dog: I will I swear,
Thou ask'st but right; and Aulus, truth to tell,
I think thy Dog deserves my love as well.

div.head: 27. Ad Tilenum.
div.l: Tilens' cause th'art old, fly not the field,
For why? this god, old men his Souldiers stil'd;
None loves but he who hath been twice a Child.

div.head: 28. To Vellius.
div.l: Thou swearst I bowl as well as most men doe,
The most are bunglers, therein thou say'st true.

div.head: 29. Three Genders.
div.l: A wife although most wise and chast,
is of the Doubtfull Gender;
A Quean oth' Common: Feminines,
are Women small and tender.

div.head: 30. Of Brawle.
div.l: Brawle loveth brabling, as he loves his life,
Leave him for dead, when he leaves stirring strife.

div.head: 31. In Paulum.
div.l: Paul, what my cloak doth hide thou fain wouldst know,
Wer't to be seen I would not cover' • so.

div.head: 32. Of sleep and death.
div.l: That death is but a sleep I not deny,
Yet when I next would sleep, I would not dye.

div.head: 33. Vpon Methusus.
div.l: Methusus ask'd me why I call'd him sot,
I answer made, because he lov'd the pot,
For while Methusus busie is with it,
The fool I'm sure's as busie with his wit.

div.head: 34. On Thraso.
div.l: Thraso goes lame with blows he did receive
In a late duell, if you'l him believe.

div.head: 35. Newes.
div.l: When News doth come, if any would discusse
The Letter of the word, resolve it thus:
News is convey'd by letter, word, or mouth,
And comes to us from North, East, West, and South.

div.head: 36. Of Rufus.
div.l: Rufus had rob'd his Host, and being put to it,
Said, I am an arrant rogue if I did doe it.

div.head: 37. Of Marcus.
div.l: When Marcus fail'd, a borrowed sum to pay,
Unto his friend at the appointed day;
Twere superstition for a man, he sayes,
To be a strict observer of set dayes.

div.head: 38. Of a Thief.
div.l: A thief arrested, and in custody
Under strong guards of armed company,
Askt why they held him so; Sir, quoth the chief,
We hold you for none other then a thief.

div.head: 39. Of Motion.
div.l: Motion brings heat, and thus we see it prov'd,
Most men are hot and angry when they'r mov'd.

div.head: 40. Formall the Fashionist.
div.l: Formall all form and fashion is, for matter,
Who sayes he sees it in him, doth but flatter;
Open and search him, you shall quickly find
With what course Canvas his soft silks are lin'd.

div.head: 41. Ad Scriptorem quend.
div.l: Halfe of your Book is to an Index growne,
You give your Book Contents, your Reader non •

div.head: 42. Riches.
div.l: Gold's th'onely God, Rich men bear rule,
Money makes Majesty:
Rich Pluto, not plain Plato now,
Speaks with applause most high.

div.head: 43. On Sextus.
div.l: Sextus doth wish his wife in Heaven were,
Where can she have more happinesse then there?

div.head: 45. Secreta nobis.
div.l: Tassus from Temple-stairs by water goes,
To Westminster, and back to Temple rowes,
Belike he loves not trot too much the street
Or surbait on the stones his tender feet:
Tut! come, there's something in't must not be known
But Sir beleev't, The debt is not his own.

div.head: 45. Of Text-corruptors.
div.l: Bad Commentators spoyle the best of Books,

So God gives meat, (they say) the Devil sends Cook •
▪

div.head: 46. On a Drawer drunk.
div.l: Drawer with thee now even is thy Wine,
For thou hast pierc'd his Hogs-head, and he thine.

div.head: 47. Vpon the weights of a Clock.
div.l: I wonder time's so swift, when as I see,
Upon her heels, such lumps of lead to be.

div.head: 48. On Cynna.
div.l: Because I am not of a Gyants stature,
Despise me no • , nor praise thy liberall nature,
For thy huge limbs; that you are great, 'tis true,
And that I'm little in respect of you:
The reason of our growths is eas'ly had,
You, many had perchance; I but one Dad.

div.head: 49 On Alastrus.
div.l: Alastrus hath nor coyn, nor spirit, nor wit.
I think hee's only then for Bedlam • it.

div.head: 50. Of Mendacio.
div.l: Mendacio pretends to tell men News:
And that it may be such, himselfe doth use
To make it: but that will no longer need,
Let him tell truth, it will be News indeed.

div.head: 51. On Landanno.
div.l: Landanno in his gallant bravery,
Ruffled his Silks, lookt big, and thrust me by:
And still as often as he meets me so,
My home-spun cloth must to the channell go.
Advise thee well Landanno, children note,
And fools admire thee for thy velvet coat:
I keep (Landanno) in repute with such,
As think they cannot scorn poor thee too much.
But thou canst squire fine Madams, thou canst vail
Thy Cap and Feather, cringe, and wag thy tail
Most decently: Now by you stars that shi • e,
So thou transcend'st me: Take the wall, 'tis thine.

div.head: 52. On Shanks.
div.l: Shanks swears he fasts; and always cryes for Beef:
O how he fasts! that's how fast eats the Theef!

div.head: 53. Cito bene.
div.l: Sir Iohn at Mattins prayes he might dispatch,
Who by true promise is to bowl a match.

div.head: 54. Of Pertinax.
div.l: It will, it must, it shall be so,
Saith Pertinax; but what's the reason trow?
Nay, that I cannot tell, nor doth he know.

div.head: 55. To valiant Dammee.
div.l: Dammee thy brain is valiant, 'tis confest;
Thou more, that with it every day dar'st jest
Thy self into fresh braules; but cal'd upon,
With swearing Damme, answer'st every one.
Keep thy self there, and think thy valour right,
He that dares Damne himself, dares more then fight.

div.head: 56. On Cornuto.
div.l: Cornuto is not jealous of his wife,
Nor e're mistrusts her too lascivious life,
Ask him the reason why he doth forbear,
Hee'l answer straight, it cometh with a fear.

div.head: 57. On a Shrew.
div.l: A froward Shrew being blam'd because she show'd
Not so much reverence as by right she ow'd
Unto her Husband, she reply'd he might
Forbear complaint of me, I do him right;
His will is mine, he would bear rule, and I
Desire the like, onely in sympathy.

div.head: 58. Of Lawlesse.
div.l: Lawlesse the worst times liketh best, why ist?
Because then Lawlesse may doe what he list.

div.head: 59. A rich Curre.
div.l: Dru dares good men deprave because hee's rich,
Whether more fool or Knave, I know not which.

div.head: 60. On a Youth married to an Old Woman.
div.l: A smooth-fac'd youth, what wedded to an old
Decrepit Shrew! (such is the power of Gold)
Thy fortune I dare tell; perchance thou'lt have
At Supper dainties, but in B • d a grave.

div.head: 61. On a Fly in a glasse.
div.l: A Fly out of his glasse a guest did take,
E're with the liquor he his thirst would slake;
When he had drunk his fill, again the Fly
Into the glasse he put, and said, though I
Love not Flyes in my drink, yet others may,
Whose humour I nor like, nor will gain-say.

div.head: 62. On Collimus.
div.l: If that Collimus any thing doe lend,
Or Dog, or Horse, or Hawk unto his friend,
He to endear the borrowers love the more,
Saith he ne'r • ent it any one before,
Nor would to any but to him: His wife
Having observ'd these speeches all her life,
Behinde him forks her fingers, and doth cry,
To none but you, I'de do this courtesie.

div.head: 63. To Loquax.
div.l: Loquax, to hold thy tongue would do thee wrong,
For thou wouldst be no man but for thy tongue.

div.head: 64. Good wits jump.
div.l: Against a post a scholler chanc'd to strike
At unawares his head; like will to like:
Good wits will jump (quoth he:) if that be true,
The title of a block-head is his due.

div.head: 65. On Womens Masks.
div.l: It seems that Masks do women much disgrace,
Sith when they wear them they do hide their face.

div.head: 66. Of Sawcy the Intruder.
div.l: Sawcy, though uninvited, is so rude,
As into every comp'ny to intrude;
But he's no fit companion for any,
Who all ways makes the number one too many.

div.head: 67. Vpon a pair of Tongs.
div.l: The burnt child dreads the fire; if this be true,
Who first invented Tongs its fury knew.

div.head: 68. Lawyers and Souldiers.
div.l: If Lawyers had for Term, a tearm of warre,
Souldiers would be as rich as Lawyers are;
But here's the difference 'tween Guns and Gowns,
These take good Angels, th'other take crack't crowns.

div.head: 69. On Momus.
div.l: Momus can call another fool, but he
Can never make his brain and wit agree.

div.head: 70. Woman.
div.l: A Woman is a Book, and often found
To prove far better in the sheets then bound:
No marvail then, why men take such delight
Above all things to study in the night.

div.head: 71. Clytus cunning.
div.l: Clytus the Barbar doth Occasion fly,
Because 'tis bald, and he gains nought thereby.

div.head: 72. Rich promises.
div.l: Lords promise soon, but to perform are long,
Then would their purse-st • ing • were ty'd to their tongue.

div.head: 73. On Comptulus.
div.l: I wonder'd Comptulus, how thy long hair,
In comely curles could show so debonair,
And every hair in order be, when as
Thou couldst not trim it by a looking glasse,
Nor any Barber did thy tresses pleat;
'Tis strange; but Monsieur I conceive the • eat
When you your hair doe kemb, you off it take,
And order't as you please for fashion sake.

div.head: 74. On Gellius.
div.l: In building of his house, Gellius hath spent
All his revenues and his ancient rent,
Ask not a reason, why Gellius is poor,
His greater house hath turn'd him out of door.

div.head: 75. To Ponticus.
div.l:
At Supper time will Pon • u •
visit me,
I'd rather have his room then company;
But if him, from me I can no ways fright,
I'd have him visit me each fasting night.

div.head: 76. Balbus.
div.l: Balbus a Verse on Venus Boy doth scan,
But ere 'twas finish'd Cupid's grown a man.

div.head: 77. On a Pot-Poet.
div.l: What lofty verses Coelus writes? it is
But when his head with wine oppressed is:
So when great drops of rain fall from the skies
In standing pools, huge bubbles will arise.

div.head: 78. On Onellus.
div.l: Thou never supp'st abroad, Onellus, true,
For at my home I'm sure to meet with you.

div.head: 79. Of professed Atheists.
div.l: If even Devils themselves believe and tremble,
Atheists profest methinks should but dissemble.

div.head: 80. To Termagant.
div.l: My Termagant, as I have ought to save,
I neither cal'd thee fool, nor knave:
That which I cal'd thee is a thing well known,
A trifle not worth thinking on:
What I suppose thy self wilt easily grant,
I cal'd thee Cuckold, Termagant.

div.head: 81. On a Vertuous Talker.
div.l: If vertue's alwayes in thy mouth, how can
It e're have time to reach thy heart, fond man?

div.head: 82. To Severus.
div.l: Beleeve Severus, that in these my Rimes
I tax no person but the common Crimes.

div.head: 83. Vpon Pigs devouring a bed of Penny-royall, commonly called Organs.
div.l: A good wife once a bed of Organs set,
The Pigs came in and eat up every whit,
The good man said, wife you your Garden may
Hogs Norton call, here Pigs on Organs play.

div.head: 84. On Gubs.
div.l: Gubs calls his children Kitlins: and wo'd bound
(Some say) for joy to see those Kitlins dround.

div.head: 85. On a Fortune-teller.
div.l: The influence of th'Stars are known to thee,
By whom thou canst each future fortune see:
Yet sith thy wife doth thee a Cuckold make,
Tis strange they do not that to thee partake.

div.head: 86. To sweet sir Ou • side.
div.l: Th'expence in Odours, is a foolish sin,
Except thou couldst sweeten thy Corps within.

div.head: 87. On a Gallant.
div.l: A glittering Gallant, from a prancing Steed,
Alighting down desir'd a boy with speed
To hold his horse a while, he made reply,
Can one man hold him fast? 'twas answer'd, I:
If then one man can hold him Sir, you may
Doe it your self, quoth he, and slunk away.

div.head: 88. To Eras-mus.
div.l: That thou'art a man each of thy learn'd works shows,
But yet thy name tels us thou wast a Mouse.

div.head: 89. On Bunce.
div.l: Money thou ow'st me; prethee fix a day
For payment promis'd, though thou never pay:
Nay when th'art honest, let me have some hope.

div.head: 90. On an empty House.
div.l: Lollus by night awak'd heard Theeves about
His house, and searching narrowly throughout
To find some pillage there, he said, you may
By night, but I can find nought here by day.

div.head: 91. A trim Barber.
div.l: Neat Barber trim, I must commend thy care,
Which dost all things exactly to a haire.

div.head: 92. On a bragging Coward.
div.l: Corsus in Camp, when as his Mates betook
Themselves to dine, encourag'd them and spoke,
Have a good stomach Lads, this night we shall
In heaven at Supper keep a festivall.
But battail join'd he fled away in hast,
And said, I had forgot, this night I fast.

div.head: 93. On a great Nose.
div.l: Thy Nose no man can wipe, Proclus, unless
He have a hand as big as Hercules:
When thou dost sneeze the sound thou dost not hear
Thy Nose is so far distant from thine ear.

div.head: 94. On an unequall pair.
div.l: Fair Phillis is to churlish Priscus wed,
As stronger wine with waters mingled;
Priscus his love to Phillis more doth glow
With fervency then fire; hers cold as snow:
'Tis well, for if their flames alike did burn,
One house would be too hot to serve their turn.

div.head: 95. In Quintum.
div.l: Quintus is burnt, and may thereof be glad,
For being poor he hath a good pretence
At every Church to crave benevolence,
For one that had by fire lost all he had.

div.head: 96. On a changeable Rayment.
div.l: Know you why Lollus changeth every day,
His Perriwig, his face, and his array?
'Tis not because his comings in are much,
Or 'cause hee'l swill it with the roaring Dutch;
But 'cause the Sergeants (who a writ have had
Long since against him) should not know the Lad.

div.head: 97. On Guesse.
div.l: Guesse cuts his shooes, and limping goes about
To have men think he's troubled with the Gou • ,
But 'tis no Gout (beleive it) but hard Beere,
Whose acrimonious humour bites him here.

div.head: 98. On Stale-Batch.
div.l: For all night-sins with other Wives unknown
Batch now doth daily penance in his own.

div.head: 99. To sir Guilty.
div.l: Guilty, be wise; and though thou knowst the crime •
Be thine I tax; yet do not own my Rimes;
'Twere madnesse in thee to betray thy fame,
And person to the world, ere I thy name.

div.head: 100. Veritas subverta.
div.l: Luke that a man on hor • -back met but late,
Would simply seem thus to equivocate,
And strong maintain 'gainst them, contend who dare,
'Twas meerly but a Taylor and a Mare.

div.head: 101. On Hugh.
div.l: Hugh should have gone to Oxford th'other day,
But turn'd at Tiburn, and so lost his way.

div.head: 102. On a Painted Madam.
div.l: Men say y'are fair; and fair ye are, 'tis true,
But (Hark!) we praise the Painter now, not you.

div.head: 103. On Barossa.
div.l: Barossa boasts his pedigree, although
He knows no letter of the Christ-Crosse row,
His house is ancient, and his gentry great,
For what more ancient e're was heard of yet
Then is the family of fools? how than
Dare you not call Barossa Gentleman?

div.head: 104. Experto credendum.
div.l: How durst Capritius call his wedlock whore,
But that he speaks it plusquam per narratum.
Nam ipse teste: what require you more,
Unlesse you'ld have it magis approbatum?

div.head: 105. On Iack Cut-purse.
div.l: Jack Cut-purse is, and hath been patient long,
For hee's content to pocket up much wrong.

div.head: 106. On Afer.
div.l: Afer hath sold his land and bought a Horse,
Whereon he pranceth to the royall Burse,
To be on hors-back he delights; wilt know?
'Cause then his Company he'd higher show:
But happy chance tall Afer in his pride,
Mounts a Gunnelly and on foot doth ride.

div.head: 107. On Charismus.
div.l: Thou hast compos'd a Book, which neither age,
Nor future time shall hurt through all their rage;
For how can future times or age invade,
That work which perished as soon as made?

div.head: 108. Facilis descensus averni.
div.l: The way to hell is easie, th'other day,
A blind man thither quickly found the way.

div.head: 109. Age and Youth.
div.l: Admire not youth, despise not age, although
Some yong are grave, most old men children grow.

div.head: 110. On Orus.
div.l: Orus sold wine, and then tobacco, now
He aqua-vitae doth his friends allow.
What e're he had was sold to save his life,
And now turn'd Pander, he doth sell his wife.

div.head: 111. On Sneape.
div.l: Sneape has a face so brittle, that it breaks
Forth into blushes, whensoere he speaks.

div.head: 112. On Acerra.
div.l: Tobacco hurts the brain Physitians say,
Doth dull the wit, and memory decay,
Yet fear not thou Acerra, for 'twill ne're
Hurt thee so much by use, as by thy feare.

div.head: 113. Empta nostra.
div.l: Madam La Foy wears not those locks for nought,
Ask at the Shop else, where the same she bought.

div.head: 114. On Briso.
div.l: Who private lives, lives well, no wonder then,
You doe absent you from the sight of men,
For out of doors you ne'r by day appear,
What, is a Sergeant such a huge Bug-bear?

div.head: 115. A Foolish Querie.
div.l: How rich a man is, all desire to know;
But none inquires if good he be or no.

div.head: 116. On the King of Swedens Picture.
div.l: Who but the half of this neat Picture drew,
That it could ne're be fully done, well knew.

div.head: 117. B. I. answer to a Thief bidding him stand.
div.l: Fly Villain hence, or by thy coat of steel,
I'le make thy heart, my brazen bullet feel,
And send that thrice as theevish soule of thine,
To Hell, to wear the Devils Valentine.

div.head: 118. Thiefs reply.
div.l: Art thou great Ben? or the revived ghost
Of famous Shakespeare? or some drunken host?
Who being tipsie with thy muddy Beer,
Dost think thy Rimes shall daunt my soule with fear?
Nay know base Slave, that I am one of those▪
Can take a purse as well in verse as prose;
And when th'art dead write this upon thy Herse,
Here lyes a Poet that was rob'd in Verse.

div.head: 119. Nothing New.
div.l: Nothing is new: we walk were others went;
Th • re's no vice now but has his president.

div.head: 120. On Cupid.
div.l: Cupid hath by his sly and subtill Art,
A certain Arrow shot, and pierc'd my heart;
What shall I doe to be reveng'd on love?
There is but one way, and that one I'le prove;
I'le steale his Arrows, and will head them new
With Womens hearts, and then they'l ne'r fly true.

lg.l: All dainty meats I doe defie▪
Which feed men fat as Swine,
He is a frugall man indeed,
That on a leaf can dine.
Hee needs no Napkin for his hands,
His fingers ends to wipe,
That keeps his Kitchin in a Box,
And Roast-meat in a Pipe.

div.head: 122. Feeble standing.
div.l: Mat being drunken, much his anger wreaks
On's wife; but stands to nothing that he speak • .

div.head: 123. Long and Lazie.
div.l: That was the Proverb. Let my Mistriss be
Lazie to others; but belong to me.

div.head: 124. On the Tobaconist.
div.l: If mans flesh be like Swines, as it is said,
The Metamorphosis is sooner made:
Then full fac'd Gnatho no Tobacco take,
Smoaking your Corps, lest Bacon you do make.

div.head: 125. Another.
div.l: Tom I commend thee above all I know,
That sold'st thy cushion for a pipe of To—
For now 'tis like if e're thou study more,
Thou' • t sit to't harder then thou didst before.

div.head: 126. On Button the Grave-maker.
div.l: Ye powers above and heavenly poles,
Are graves become but Button-holes?

div.head: 127. On long haire.
div.l: Lucas long hair down to his shoulders wears,
And why? he dares not cut it for his ears.

div.head: 128. To a stale Lady.
div.l: Thy wrinkles are no more, nor lesse,
Then beauty turn'd to sowernesse.

div.head: 129. A Crab is restorative.
div.l: The Crab of the wood
Is sawce very good,
For the Crab of the foaming Sea;
But the wood of a Crab
Is sawce for a drab
That will not her husband obey.

div.head: 130. Alius altior.
div.l: Would you with Cajus offer now confer
In such familiar sort as heretofore?
And not observe he's grown an Officer,
That looks for adoration ten times more?
Tut! what of pedegree, or turpe domo,
Tis not so now ye see, nam ecce homo.

div.head: 131. Sor • e tua contentas.
div.l: If adverse fortune bring to passe,
And will that thou an Asse must be;
Then be an asse, and live an asse,
For out of question wise is he
That undergoes with humble mind,
The state that chance hath him assign'd.

div.head: 132. On a pretender to Prophecy.
div.l: Ninety two years the world as yet shall stand,
If it doe stand or fall at your command;
But say, why plac'd you not the worlds end ny • r
L • st ere you dy'd you might be prov'd a lyer?

div.head: 133. Mart. lib. 8. Epigr. 69.
div.l: Old Poets onely thou dost praise,
And none but dead ones magnifie,
Pardon Vocerta, thee to please,
I am not yet in mind to die.

div.head: 134. On a Gamester.
div.l: For hundred-thousands Matho playes;
Olus what's that to thee?
Not thou by means thereof, I trow,
But Matho poor shall be.

div.head: 135. Parcus profusus.
div.l: Old doting Claudus that rich miser known,
Made drunk one night, & jumping but with Ioan,
Was forc't not onely to discharge the shot,
But keep the Bastard which the gull ne'r got.

div.head: 136. On Fr. Drake.
div.l: Sir Drake, whom well the worlds end knew,
Which thou didst compasse round,
And whom both Poles of Heaven once saw,
Which North and South do bound.
The Stars above would make thee known,
If men here silent were;
The Sun himselfe cannot forget,
His fellow Traveller.

div.head: 137. B. I. approbation of a copy of Verses.
div.l: One of the witty sort of Gentlemen,
That held society with learned Ben—
Shew'd him some Verses of a tragick sense;
Which did his ear much curious violence;
But after Ben had been a kind partaker
Of the sad lines, he needs must know the maker;
What unjust man he was, that spent his time,
And banish'd reason to advance his rime:
Nay gentle Ben, replyes the Gentleman,
I see I must support the Poet than;
Although those humble strains are not so fit
For to please you, hee's held a pretty wit;
Is he held so? (sayes Ben) so may a Goos,
Had I the holding, I would let him loos.

div.head: 138. Vt pluma persona.
div.l: Why wears Laurentius such a lofty feather?
Because he's proud and foolish both together.

div.head: 139. Gaine and Gettings.
div.l: When others gain much by the present cast,
The Coblers getting time, is at the last.

div.head: 140. Domina praedominatis.
div.l: Ill may Radulphus boast of rule or riches,
That lets his wife rule him, and wear the breeches.

div.head: 141. On Doll.
div.l: Doll she so soon began the wanton trade,
She ne'r remembers that she was a maid.

div.head: 142. To a Nose and Teeth very long.
div.l: Gape 'gainst the Sun, and by thy Teeth and Nose
'Tis easie to perceive how the day goes.

div.head: 143. On a Welshman and an Englishman.
div.l: There was a time a difference began,
Between a Welshman and an Englishman,
And thus it was; the Englishman would stand
Against all Argument, that this our land
Was freest of her fruits: there is a place,
Quoth he, whose ground so fruitfull is of grasse,
But throw a staffe in't but this night, you shall
Not see't the morrow, 'twould be cover'd all.
The Welshman cry'd, 'tis true it might lye under
The o'r-grown grasse, wch is with us no wonder:
For turn your Horse into our fruitfull ground,
And before morning come, he shan't be found.

div.head: 144. On Pride.
div.l: Why Pride to others doth her self prefer,
The reason's clear, she's heir to Lucifer.

div.head: 145. On Skrew.
div.l: Skrew lives by shifts, yet swears by no small oaths,
For all his shifts, he cannot shift his cloaths.

div.head: 146. O Mores.
div.l: Now vertu's hid with follies jugling mist,
And hee's no man that is no humorist.

div.head: 147. To Teltale.
div.l: Thy glowing ears, to hot contention bent,
Are not unlike red Herrings broyl'd 〈…〉 .

div.head: 148. Sperando pariens.
div.l: Hodg hir'd him such a house, at such a rent,
As might 'gainst marriage, much his state augment;
But lingring fates did so his hopes prevent,
As Hodg perforce must flye, for all was spent.

div.head: 149. On a Souldier.
div.l: The Souldier fights well, and with good regard,
But when he's lame, he lyes at an ill ward.

div.head: 150. Vivens mortuis.
div.l: What makes young Brutus bear so high his head,
And on the sudden gallant it so brave?
Pray understand Sir; 's Father's newly dead,
Who hath so long been wish'd for laid in's grave.

div.head: 151. A secret necessity.
div.l: What makes F. G. wear still one pair of hose?
Ask Banks the Broker; he the businesse knows.

div.head: 152. On Garret and Chambers.
div.l: Garret and his friend Chambers having done
Their City businesse, walkt to Paddington,
And coming neer the fatall place, where men,
I mean offender • , ne'r return agen,
Looking on Tyburn in a merriment:
Sayes Chambers, here's a pretty Tenement
Had it a Garret? Garret hearing that,
Replyes, friend Chambers I doe wonder at
Your simple censure, and could mock you for it,
There must be Chambers e're there be a Garret.

div.head: 153. Dubium indubitatum.
div.l: Say Parnels children prove not one like th'other;
The best is yet, she's sure they'd both one Mother.

div.head: 154. On Linnit.
div.l: And sweetly sings, but yet his breath sayes no.

div.head: 155. On Vsuring Gripe.
div.l: Gripe feels no lameness of his knotty Gout,
His moneys travell for him in and out.
And though the soundest legs goe every day,
He toyls to be at Hell as soon as they.

div.head: 156. A phrase in Poetry.
div.l: Fairer then that word faire, why so she must,
Or be as black as Timothies toasted crust.

div.head: 157. A Witt-all.
div.l: Ieppa thy wit will ne'r endure a touch,
Thou knowst so little, and dost speak so much

div.head: 158. Ad Lectorem.
div.l: Is't possible that thou my Book hast bought,
That said'st 'twas nothing worth? why was it nought?
Read it agen, perhaps thy wit was dull,
Thou may'st find something at the second pull:
Indeed at first thou nought didst understand;
For shame get something at the second hand.

div.head: 159. On Skinns.
div.l: Skinns he din'd well to day; how doe you think?
His nayles they were his meat, his reume the drink?

div.head: 160. Suum cuique pulchrum.
div.l: Posthumus not the last of many more,
Asks why I write in such an idle vain,
Seeing there are of Epigrams such store;
O give me leave to tell thee once again,
That Epigrams are fitted to the season,
Of such as best know how to make rime reason.

div.head: 161. Certa dissimulans.
div.l: Monsieur Piero's wise trades all in French,
And coyly simpring cryes, Pardona moy:
As who should think, she's sure no common wench
But a most true dissembler, par may foy.

div.head: 162. In magnis voluisse sat est.
div.l: In matters great to will it doth suffice:
I blush to hear how loud this Proverb lyes,
For they that owe great sums by bond or bill,
Can never cancell them with meer good will.

div.head: 163. As proud as witlesse Dracus.
div.l: Dracus his head is highly by him born.
And so by straws are empty heads of corn.

div.head: 164. Saltem videretur.
div.l: A Welshman and an Englishman disputed,
Which of their lands maintain'd the greatest state;
The Englishman the Welshman quite confuted,
Yet would the Welshman nought his brags abate,
Ten cooks, quoth he, in Wales one wedding fees,
Truth, quoth the other, each man tosts his cheese.

div.head: 165. Knowing and not knowing.
div.l: Cosmus by custome taunts each man,
And yet can nought of reason scan,
How can that be, when who knows least,
Knows he should wise be, that would jest:
Then thus no further I allow,
That Cosmus know • , but knows not how.

div.head: 166. Stupid Binus.
div.l: Sith time flyes fast away, his safest flight,
Binus prevents with dreaming day and night.

div.head: 167. Postrema pessima.
div.l: Cacus in's cunning ne'r so prov'd o'r-reacht
As now at last, who must be halter-stretcht▪

div.head: 168. On his Mistris.
div.l: My Love and I for kisses play'd,
She would keep stakes, I was content,
And when I won she would be paid;
This made me ask her what she meant,
Saith she, since you are in this wrangling vain,
Take you your kisses, and give me mine again.

div.head: 169. On a proud Maid.
div.l: She that will eat her breakfast in her bed,
And spend the morn in dressing of her head,
And sit at dinner like a Maiden-bride,
God in mercy may doe much to save her,
But what a case is he in that shall have her?

div.head: 170. Tempus edax rerum.
div.l: Time eateth all things, could the Po • ts say,
The times are chang'd, our times drink all away.

div.head: 171. Facies ignota.
div.l: Why should not Rubin rich apparell wear,
That's left more money then an Asse can bear?
Can any guesse him by his outward guise,
But that he may be generous and wise?

div.head: 172. On a coy Woman.
div.l: She seems not won, yet won she is at length;
In loves war, women use but half their strength.

div.head: 173. On Bed-keeping.
div.l: Bradus the Smith hath often sworn and sed,
That no disease should make him keep his bed,
His reason was, I oft have heard him tell it,
He wanted money, therefore he would sell it.

div.head: 174. On a man stealing a Candle from a Lanthorn.
div.l: One walking in the street a winter night,
Climb'd to a Lanthorn, thought t' • ave stole the light,
But taken in the manner and descri'd
By one o'th'servants, who look'd & cry'd,
Whose there: what d'you? who doth our lanthorn handle?
Nothing, said he, but onely snuffe the Candle.

div.head: 175. On Fraternus.
div.l: Fraternus' opinions show his reason weak,
He held the nose was made for man to speak.

div.head: 176. Little and Loud.
div.l: Little you are; for womens sake be proud;
For my sake next, (though little) be not loud.

div.head: 177. On a French Fencer, that challenged Church an English Fencer.
div.l: The fencing Gaules in pride and gallant vaunt,
Challeng'd the English at the Fencing skill,
The Fencer Church, or the Church Militant,
His errors still reprov'd and knock'd him still;
But sith our Church him disciplin'd so sore,
He (rank Recusant) comes to Church no more.

div.head: 178. On Gella.
div.l: Gella is light, and like a Candle wasteth,
Even to the snuffe, that stinketh more it lasteth.

div.head: 179. On I. Lipsius who bequeathed his Gown to the V. Mary.
div.l: A dying Latinist of great renown,
Unto the Virgin Mary gave his Gown;
And was not this false Latine so to joyn
With female gender, the case masculine?

div.head: 180. On two striving together.
div.l: Two falling out, into a ditch they fell,
Their falling out, was ill; but in was well.

div.head: 181. A Lawyers Will.
div.l: A Lawyer being sick and extream ill,
Was moved by his friends to make his wil,
Which soon he did, gave all the wealth he had
To frantick persons, lunatick, and mad;
And to his friends this reason did reveale;
(That they might see, with equity hee'd deal)
From mad mens hands I did my wealth receive,
Therefore that wealth to mad mens hands I leave.

div.head: 182. Youth and Age.
div.l: Age is deformed, Youth unkind,
We scorn their bodies, they our mind.

div.head: 183. Somnus decipiens.
div.l: Dod sweetly dreamt this other night had found
In gold and silver ne'r an hundred pound,
But waking felt he was with Fleas sore bitten,
And further smelt he had his shirt be—

div.head: 184. To a Shoomaker.
div.l: What boots it thee, to follow such a trade,
That's alwayes under foot and underlaid?

div.head: 185. Death.
div.l: The lives of men seem in two seas to swim,
Death comes to young folks, and old go to him.

div.head: 186. Quos ergo, &c.
div.l: Rufus in rage the Pots flings down the stairs,
And threats to pull the Drawer by the ears,
For giving such attendance: Slave (sayes he)
Where's thine observance? Ha! must such as we
Be no more waited on? Goe; bring to pay,
And keep my Rapier till I come this way.

div.head: 187. A disparity.
div.l: Children fondly blab truth,
and fools their brothers;
Women have learn'd more wisdome
of their Mothers.

div.head: 188. To Maledict.
div.l: Thou speakest ill, not to give men their dues,
But speakest ill, because thou canst not chuse.

div.head: 189. On Newter Ned.
div.l: Newter convict of publick wrongs to men,
Takes private beatings, and begins agen;
Two kinds of valour he doth shew at once,
Active in's brains, and passive in his bones.

div.head: 190. Interpone tuis, &c.
div.l: Not mirth, nor care alone, but inter-wreath'd;
Care gets mirths stomach, mirth makes care long breath'd.

div.head: 191. Ignotus sibi.
div.l: Fastidius finds it Nimis ultra posse,
How to distinguish of Teipsum nosce:
I doe not marvell much it should be so,
For why the Coxcomb, will himselfe not know.

div.head: 192. On Craw.
div.l: Craw cracks in Sirrop; and do's stinking say,
Who can hold that (my friends) that will away.

div.head: 193. Pot Poet.
div.l: Poet and pot differ but in a letter,
Which makes the Poet love the pot the better.

div.head: 194. Content.
div.l: Content is all we aim at with our store?
If that be had with little, what needs more?

div.head: 195. Fast and Loose.
div.l: Paphus was marry'd all in hast,
And now to rack doth run;
So knitting of himself too fast,
He hath himselfe undone.

div.head: 196. Tortus.
div.l: Tortus accus'd to lye, to fawn, to flatter;
Said he but set a good face on the matter;
Then sure he borrow'd it, for 'tis well known,
Tortus ne're wore a good face of his own.

div.head: 197. On Raspe.
div.l: Raspe playes at Nine-holes, and 'tis known he get •
But of his gettings there's but little signe,
When one hole wasts more then he gets by nine.

div.head: 198. Impar impares odit.
div.l: Sotus hates wise men, for himselfe is none,
And fools he hates, because himself is one.

div.head: 199. Similis doctrina libello.
div.l: Croesus of all things loveth not to buy
So many Books of such diversity:
Your Almanack (sayes he) yeelds all the sence
Of time's past, profit, and experience.

div.head: 200. On Tullus.
div.l: Tullus who was a Taylor by profession,
Is late turn'd Lawyer, and of large possession.
So who before did cut but Countrey freeze,
Now cuts the Countrey in excessive fees.

div.head: 201. Vt parta perdita.
div.l: Marcellus proves a man of double means,
First rais'd by drunkards, then undone by queans.

div.head: 202. On Iack and Iill.
div.l: Since Iack and Iill both wicked be;
It seems a wonder unto me,
That they no better doe agree.

div.head: 203. On Women.
div.l: Woman's the centre, and the lines be men,
The circles, love; how doe they differ then?
Circles draw many lines into the center,
But love gives leave to onely one to enter.

div.head: 204. On Womans love.
div.l: A womans love is like a Syrian flow'r,
That buds, and spreads, and withers in an hour.

div.head: 205. On Cooke a Cuckold.
div.l: A young Cook marry'd upon Sunday last,
And he grew old e'r Tuesday night was past.

div.head: 206. Nomine, non re.
div.l: Grace I confesse it, hath a comely face,
Good hand and foot as answerable to it:
But what's all this except she had more grace?
Oh you will say, 'tis want that makes her do it.
True, want of grace indeed, the more her shame:
Gracelesse by Nature, onely Grace by Name.

div.head: 207. A Mounsieur Naso, vero le.
div.l: Naso let none drink in his glasse but hee,
Think you 'tis pride? 'tis courtesie.

div.head: 208. A Butcher marrying a Tanners daughter.
div.l: A fitter match then this could not have bin,
For now the flesh is married to the skin.

div.head: 209. A Widow.
div.l: He which for's wife a widow doth obtain,
Doth like to those that buy clothes in Long-lane,
One Coat's not fit, another's too too old,
Their faults I know not, but th'are manifold.

div.head: 110. On a Farmer Knighted.
div.l: In my conceit Sir Iohn, you were to blame,
To make a quiet good-wife, a mad-dame.

div.head: 211. On Pallas and Bacchus Birth.
div.l: Pallas the off-spring of Ioves brain,
Bacchus out of his thigh was ta'en:
He breaks his brain that learning wins,
When he that's drunk breaks but his shin • .

div.head: 212. On an old man doting upon a young Wench.
div.l: A rich old man loving a fair young Lasse,
Out of his breeches his spectacles drew,
Wherewith he writ a note how rich he was;
All which (quoth he) sweet heart I'l give to you.
Excuse me Sir (quoth she) for all your riches,
I'l marry none that wears his eyes in's breeches.

div.head: 213. On a Welshman.
div.l: The way to make a Welshman think on blisse,
And daily say his prayers on his knees,
Is to perswade him, that most certain 'tis,
The Moon is made of nothing but green Cheese;
Then he'l desire of Iove no greater boon,
Then to be plac'd in Heaven to eat the Moon.

div.head: 214. On Lungs.
div.l: Lungs (as some say) ne'r sets him down to eat,
But that his breath doth fly-blow all his meat.

div.head: 215. Ad Quintum.
div.l: Thy lawfull wife, fair Lelia needs must be,
For she was forc'd by law to marry thee.

div.head: 216. As many dayes in the year, so many Veins in man.
div.l: That every thing we doe, might vain appear,
We have a vein for each day in the year.

div.head: 217. To a friend, on the losse of his Mistresse.
div.l: I • thou the best of women didst forgo,
Weigh if thou found'st her, or didst make her so:
If she was found, know there is more then one;
If made, the workman lives though she be gone▪

div.head: 218. On a Whore.
div.l: Rosa is faire, but not a proper woman;
Can any woman proper be that's common?

div.head: 219. Aequalis consensus.
div.l: Caecus and's choyce, for change no time defers,
Both separate, yet consenting each together,
He maids for his turn takes, she men for hers,
And so they jump, though seldome joyn together▪

div.head: 220. On a Welshman
div.l: A Welshman late coming into an Inne,
Asked the Maid what meat there was within;
Cow-heels she answer'd, and a brest of Mutton;
But quoth the Welshman, since I am no glutton;
Either of both shall serve; to night the brest,
The heels i'th morning, then light meat is best;
At night he took the brest, and did not pay,
I'th morning took his heels, and run away.

div.head: 221. On Men and Women.
div.l: Ill thrives that haplesse family that shows
A Cock that's silent, and a Hen that crows:
I know not which lives more unnaturall lives,
Obeying Husbands, or commanding Wives.

div.head: 222. On Linus.
div.l: Linus told me of Verses that he made,
Riding to London on a trotting Jade;
I should have known, had he conceal'd the case,
Even by his Verses of his Horses pace.

div.head: 223. Sauce for sorrowes.
div.l: Although our sufferings meet with no reliefe,
An equall mind is the best sauce for griefe.

div.head: 224. On a little dimunitive Band.
div.l: What is the reason of God-dam-me's band,
Inch-deep, and that his fashion doth not alter?
God-dam-me saves a labour, understand,
In pulling't off when he puts on the halter.

div.head: 225. On fine apparrell.
div.l: Some that their wives may neat and cleanly go,
Doe all their substance upon them bestow:
But who a Gold-finch, fain would make his wife,
Makes her perhaps a Wag-tail all her life.

div.head: 226. Vpon Conscience.
div.l: Many men this present age dispraise,
And think men have small conscience now adays;
But sure, I'l lay no such fault to their charge,
I rather think their conscience is too large.

div.head: 227. Dicta praedicta.
div.l: Battus breaks jests on any thing that's spoken,
Provided alwayes, they before are broken.

div.head: 228. On Vmber.
div.l: Vmber was painting of a Lyon fierce,
And working it, by chance from Vmbers Erse
Flew out a crack, so mighty, that the fart,
(As Vmber swears) did make his Lyon start.

div.head: 229. In Cornutum.
div.l: Cornutus cal'd his wife both whore and slut,
Quoth she, you'l never your brawling but—
But what quoth he? quoth she, the post or door,
For you have horns to butt, if I'm a whore.

div.head: 230. A witty passage.
div.l: An old man sitting at a Christmasse feast,
By eating Brawn occasioned a jest;
For whilst his tongue and gums chased about,
For want of pales the chased Bore broke out;
And light perchance upon a handsome lasse,
That neer him at the Table placed was;
Which when she spy'd, she pluck'd out of her sleeve
A pin, and did it to the old man give;
Saying, sith your Brawn out of your mouth doth slip,
Sir take this pin, and therewith close your lip;
And bursting into laughter, strain'd so much,
As with that strain her back-part spake low-dutch
Which th'old man hearing, did the pin restore;
And bad her therewith close her postern door.

div.head: 231. On Cob.
div.l: Cob clouts his shooes, and as the story tels,
His thumb-nayles par'd afford him sparables.

div.head: 232. Omnia pariter.
div.l: Ralph reads a line or two, and then cryes mew;
Deeming all else according to those few;
Thou might'st have thought and prov'd a wiser Lad;
(As Ioan her fooding bought) som good som bad.

div.head: 233. A new married Bride.
div.l: The first of all our sex came from the side of Man,
I thither am return'd from whence I came.

div.head: 234. On a Pudding.
div.l: The end of all, and in the end,
the praise of all depends.
A Pudding merits double praise,
because it hath two ends.

div.head: 235. Answer.
div.l: A pudding hath two ends; you lye my brother
For it begins at one, and ends at th'other.

div.head: 236. Si nihil attuloris, ibis, &c.
div.l: Planus, an honest Swaine, but moneylesse,
Besought a Lawyer to be good unto him,
Who either (gratis) must his cause redresse,
Or promise what he never meant to doe him.
Being asked why he carelesse lingred it?
Made this reply, Ex nihilo nihil sit.

div.head: 237. On Maids.
div.l: Most Maids resemble Eve now in their lives,
Who are no sooner women, then th'are wives;
As Eve knew no man, e'r fruit wrought her wo;
So these have fruit oft e'r their husbands know.

div.head: 238. Vt cecidit surgit.
div.l: Now Martha married is, shee'l brave it out,
Though ne'r so needy known to all about;
And reason good, she rise once in her life,
That fell so oft before she was a wife.

div.head: 239. On a man whose choyce was to be hang'd or married.
div.l: M. Lo here's the Bride, and there's the Tree,
Take which of these best liketh thee.
R. The choyce is bad on either part,
The woman's worst, drive on the Cart.

div.head: 240. Women.
div.l: Were women as little as they are good;
A Pescod would make them a gown and a hood.

div.head: 241. On a Louse.
div.l: A Louse no reason hath to deal so ill,
With them of whom she hath so much her will;
She hath no tongue to speak ought in their praise,
But to backbite them finds a tongue alwayes.

div.head: 242. A Courtier and a Scholler meeting.
div.l: A Courtier proud walking along the street,
Hap'ned by chance a Scholler for to meet:
The Courtier said (minding nought more then place,
Unto the Scholler (meeting face to face)
To take the wall, base men I'l not permit;
The Scholler said, I will; and gave him it.

div.head: 243. Cede majoribus.
div.l: I took the wall, one rudely thrust me by,
And told me the High-way did openly,
I thank'd him that he would me so much grace,
To take the worse and leave the better place;
For if by owners we esteem of things,
The wall's the Subject • , but the way the Kings.

div.head: 244. On Betty.
div.l: Sound teeth has Betty, pure as pearle and small,
With mellow lips, and luscious therewithall.

div.head: 245. A rule for Courtiers.
div.l: He that will thrive in Court, must oft become,
Against his will, both blind, and deaf, and dumb •

div.head: 246. Why women wear a fall.
div.l: A question 'tis, why women wear a fall;
The truth it is, to pride they're given all,
And pride, the Proverb sayes, will have a fall.

div.head: 247. For as expertus.
div.l: Priscus hath been a traveller, for why?
He will so strangely swagger, swear and ly.

div.head: 248. To a painted Whore.
div.l: Whosoever saith thou sellest all, doth jest,
Thou buy'st thy beauty, that sells all the rest.

div.head: 249. Detur quod meritum.
div.l: A Courtier kind in speech, curst in condition,
Finding his faults could be no longer hidden,
Came to his friend to clear his bad suspition,
And fearing least he should be more then chidden▪
Fell to flatt'ring and most base submission,
Vowing to kisse his foot if he were bidden.
My foot said he? nay that were too submisse;
You three foot higher, well deserve to kisse.

div.head: 250. Non lubens loquitur.
div.l: Gluto, at meals is never heard to talk,
For which the more his chaps and chin do walk,
When every one that sits about the bord,
Makes sport to ask, what Gluto, ne'r a word?
He forc'd to answer being very loath,
I • almost choak'd, speaking and eating both.

div.head: 251. On Philos.
div.l: If Philos, none but those are dead, doe praise,
I would I might displease him all his dayes.

div.head: 252. The promise-breaker.
div.l: Ventus doth promise much, but still doth break,
So all his promises are great and weak:
Like bubbles in the water (round and light)
Swelling so great, that they are broke out-right,

div.head: 253. Change.
div.l: What now we like, anon we disapprove;
The new successor drives away old love.

div.head: 254. On a passing Bell.
div.l: This dolefull musick of impartiall death,
Who danceth after, danceth out of breath.

div.head: 255. Nummos & demona jungit▪
div.l: Bat bids you swell with envy till you burst,
So he be rich, and may his coffers fill,
Bringing th'example of the Fox that's curst
And threatning folks who have least power to kill •
For why 'tis known, his trade can never fall,
That hath already got the Devill and all.

div.head: 256. Nil gratum ratione carens.
div.l: Paulus a Pamphlet doth in prose present
Unto his Lord (the fruits of idle time)
Who far more carelesse, then therewith content,
Wisheth it were converted into rime:
Which done, and brought him at another season,
Said: now 'tis rime, before nor rime nor reason.

div.head: 257. Non cessat perdere lusor.
div.l: Ask Ficus how his luck at dicing goes:
Like to the tide (quoth he) it ebbes and flows,
Then I suppose his chance cannot be good,
For all men know 'tis longer ebbe than flood.

div.head: 258. Womens policy.
div.l: To weep oft, still to flatter, sometime spin,
Are properties women excell men in.

div.head: 259. Volucrem sic decipit auceps.
div.l: Hidrus the Horse-courser (that cunning mate)
Doth with the buyers thus equivocate;
Claps on his hand, and prays he may not thrive,
If that his gelding be not under five. ☞

div.head: 260. Perdat qui caveat emptor.
div.l: Nor lesse meant Promus when that vow he made
Then to give o'r his cousening Tapsters trade,
Who check'd for short and frothy measure, swore
He never would from henceforth fill pot more.

div.head: 261. On Death.
div.l: How base hath sin made man, to fear a thing
Which men call Mors? wch yet hath lost all sting,
And is but a privation as we know,
Nay is no word if we exempt the O:
Then let good men the fear of it defie,
All is but O, when they shall come to dye.

div.head: 262. To Mr. Ben Iohnson, demanding the reason why he call'd his playes works.
div.l: Pray tell me Ben. where doth the mystery lurk,
What others call a play, you call a work.

div.head: 263. Thus answer'd by a friend in Ben Iohnsons defence.
div.l: The Authors friend thus for the Author sayes,
Bens plays are works, when others works are plays.

div.head: 264. On Crambo a lowsie shifter.
div.l: By want of shift, since Lice at first are bred,
And after by the same increast and fed;
Crambo I muse how you have Lice so many,
Since all men know, you shift as much as any.

div.head: 265. Ad Aristarchum.
div.l: Be not agriev'd, my humorous line • afford
Of looser language here and there a word:
Who undertakes to sweep a common sink,
I cannot blame him, though his broom do stink.

div.head: 266. In Aulum.
div.l: Aulus gives naught, men say, though much he crave
Yet I can tell to whom the Pox he gave.

div.head: 267. On covetous persons.
div.l: Patrons are Latrons, then by this
Th'are worst of greedy people,
Whose cognizance a Wolfs head is,
And in his mouth a steeple.

div.head: 268. On a Dyer.
div.l: Who hath time hath life, that he denies,
This man hath both, yet still he dies.

div.head: 269. Non verbera, sed verba.
div.l: Two Schollars late appointed for the field;
Must, which was weakest to the other yield;
The quarrell first began about a word,
Which now should be decided by the sword:
But e'r they drew, there fell that alteration,
As they grew friends again by disputation.

div.head: 270. Love and Liberty.
div.l: • ove he that will; it b • st likes mee
• o have my neck from loves yoke free.

div.head: 271 To a neat reader.
div.l: • hou say'st my verses are rude, ragged, ruffe,
• ot like some others rimes, smooth dainty stuffe •
• pigrams are like Satyrs, rough without,
• ike Chesnuts sweet, take thou the kernell out.

div.head: 272. Of Letting.
div.l: • n bed a young man with his old wife lay▪
O wife, quoth he, I've let a thing to day,
By which I fear, I am a loser much:
His wife replyes, youths bargains still are such;
So turning from him angry at her heart,
She unawares let out a thundring—
O wife, quoth hee, no loser am I now,
A marv'lous saver I am made by you;
Young men that old wives have may never sell;
Because old wives, quoth hee, let things so well,

div.head: 273. Sublata causa &c.
div.l: Why studies Silvester no more the lawes,
'Tis thought Duck-lane has tane away the cause.

div.head: 274. Sapiat qui dives, oportet.
div.l: 'Tis known how well I live, sayes Romeo,
And whom I list, I'le love, or will despise:
Indeed it's reason good it should be so:
For they that wealthy are, must needs be wise:
But this were ill, if so it come to passe,
That for your wealth you must be beg'd an 〈◊〉

div.head: 275. In Dossum.
div.l: Dosse riding forth, the wind was very big,
And strained court' • ie with his Perriwig,
Leaving his sconce behind so voyd of haire,
As Esops Crow might break her Oyster there;
Fool he to think his hair could tarry fast,
When Boreas tears forrests with a blast.

div.head: 276. Post dulcia, finis amarus.
div.l: Ienkin a Welshman that had suits in Law,
Journying to London, chanc'd to steal a Cow;
For which (pox on her luck as ne'r mon saw)
Was burnt within the fist and know not how:
Being ask'd if well the Lawes with him did stand▪
Hur have hur now (quoth Ienkin) in hur hand.

div.head: 277. Feminae Iudificantur viros.
div.l: Kind Katharine to her Husband kis • these words,
Mine own sweet Will, how dearly doe I love thee▪
If true (quoth VVill) the world no such affords.
And that it's true, I durst his warrant bee;
For ne'r heard I of woman good or ill,
But alwayes loved best, her owne sweete will.

div.head: 278. Ad Tusserum.
div.l: Tusser, They tell me when thou wert alive,
Thou teaching thrift, thy self couldst never thrive;
So like the wh •• stone many men are wont
To sharpen others when themselves are blunt.

div.head: 229. Praestat videri quam esse.
div.l: Clitus with clients is well customed,
That hath the Lawes but little studied;
No matter Clitus, so they bring their fees,
How ill the case and thy advice agrees.

div.head: 280. Tunc • ua res agitur.
div.l: A jealous Marchant that a Sailor me • ,
Ask'd him the reason why he meant to marry,
Knowing what ill their absence might beget,
That still at Sea, constrained are to tarry?
Sir (quoth the saylor) think you that so strange?
'Tis done the time whiles you but walke th'exchange.

div.head: 281. On Skoles.
div.l: Skoles stinks so deadly, that his breeches loath
His dampish but tocks furthermore to cloth:
Cloyd they are up with Arse; but hope, and blast
Will whirle about, and blow them thence at last.

div.head: 282. A Conference.
div.l: A Dane, a Spaniard, a Polonian,
My self a Swisse, with an Hungarian,
At supper met, discoursed each with other,
Drank, laught, yet none that understood another.

div.head: 283. In Marcum.
div.l: Marcus is not an hypocrite, and why?
He flyes all good, to fly hypocrisy.

div.head: 284. Quod non verba suadeant?
div.l: Sextus halfe sav'd his credit with a jest,
That at a reckoning this devise had got,
When he should come to draw amongst the rest,
And saw each man had coyn, himself had not;
His empty pocket feels, and 'gins to say,
In sadnesse Sirs, here's not a crosse to pay.

div.head: 285. Stupid Binus.
div.l: Sith time flyes fast away, his safest flight
Binus prevents with dreaming day and night.

div.head: 286. In divites.
div.l: Rich men their wealth as Children Rattles keep,
When play'd a while with't then they fall asleep.

div.head: 287. In Fannium.
div.l: What fury's this? his foe whilst Fannius flyes,
He kils himself, for fear of death he dyes.

div.head: 288. On a vaunting Poetaster.
div.l: Cecilius boasts his Verses worthy be
To be ingraven on a Cypresse tree;
A Cypresse wreath befits them well, 'tis true;
For they are near their death and crave but due.

div.head: 289. In divites iracundo • .
div.l: Rich friends 'gainst poor to anger still are prone:
It is not well but profitably done.

div.head: 290. Durum telum necessitas.
div.l: Coquus with hunger pennilesse constrain'd
To call for meat and wine three shillings cost,
Had suddenly this project entertain'd,
In stead of what's to pay, to call mine host;
Who being come entreateth him discusse,
What price the Law alots for shedding blood:
Whereto mine Host directly answers thus;
'Twas alwayes forty pence he understood:
So then, quoth Coquus, to requite your pains,
Pray break my head, and give me what remains▪

div.head: 291. To an upstart.
div.l: Thy old friends thou forgotst having got wealth▪
No marvaile, for thou hast forgot thy selfe.

div.head: 292. Ambition.
div.l: In wayes to greatnesse, think on this,
That slippery all Ambition is.

div.head: 293. Suum cuiq • e.
div.l: A strange contention being lately had,
Which kind of Musick was the sweet'st and best,
Some praise the sprightly sound, and some the sad
Some lik't the Viols; and among the rest,
Some in the Bag-pipes commendation spoke,
Quoth one stood by, give me a pipe of smoke.

div.head: 294. In Prodigum.
div.l: Each age of men new fashions doth invent;
Things which are old, young men do not esteem▪
What pleasd our Fathers, doth not us content:
What flourish'd then, we out of fashion deem:
And that's the cause as I doe understand,
Why Prodigus did sell his Fathers Land.

div.head: 295. In Medicum.
div.l: When Mingo cryes, how do you sir? 'tis thought
He Patients wanteth; and his practice's naught:
Wherefore of late, now every one he meeteth,
With [I am glad to see you well] he greeteth:
But who'l believe him now, when all can tell,
The world goes ill with him, when all are well?

div.head: 296. On Zelot.
div.l: Is Zelot pure? he is: yee see he wears
The signe of Circumcision in his ears.

div.head: 297. Crispati crines plumae dant calcar amori.
div.l: Why is young Annas thus with feathers dight?
And on his shoulder wears a dangling lock?
The one foretels hee'l sooner fly then fight,
The other shows hee's wrapt in's mothers smock.
But wherefore wears he such a jingling spur?
O know, he deals with Jades that will not stir.

div.head: 298. On Boung-Bob.
div.l: Bob, thou, nor souldier, theef, nor fencer art,
Yet by thy weapon liv'st, th'hast one good part,

div.head: 299. On Glaucus.
div.l: Glaucus a man, a womans hair doth wear,
But yet he wears the same comb'd out behind:
So men the wallet of their faults doe bear,
For if before him, he that fault should find:
I think foul shame would his faire face invade,
To see a man so like a woman made.

div.head: 300. On Crab.
div.l:
Crab faces gowns with sundry Furres; 'tis know •
▪
He keeps the Fox-furre for to face his own.

div.head: 301. Dolo intimus.
div.l: Nor Hauk, nor Hound, nor Hors, those letters hhh ▪
But ach it self, 'tis Brutus bones attaches.

div.head: 302. Of Batardus.
div.l: Batardus needs would know his Horoscope,
To see if he were born to scape the rope:
The Magus said, ere thou mine answer have,
I must the name of both thy parents crave:
That said, Batardus could not speak but spit;
For on his fathers name he could not hit:
And out of doors at last he stept with shame,
To ask his mother for his fathers name.

div.head: 303. Consuetudo lex.
div.l: Two wooers for a wench were each at strife,
Which should enjoy her to his wedded wife,
Quoth th'one, she's mine, because I first her saw;
She's mine, quoth th'other, by Pye-corner law •
Where sticking once a prick on what you buy,
It's then your own, which no man must deny.

div.head: 304. On Womens deniall.
div.l: Women, although they ne're so goodly make it,
Their fashion is but to say no, and take it.

div.head: 305. In Battum.
div.l: Battus affirm'd no Poet ever writ,
Before that love inspir'd his dull-head wit:
And that himself in love had wit no more,
Then one stark mad, though somwhat wise before.

div.head: 306. On Marriage.
div.l: Wedding and hanging the Destinies dispatch,
But hanging seems to some the better match.

div.head: 307. Vidua aurata.
div.l: Gallus hath got a widow wondrous old,
The reason is he woo'd her for her gold:
Knowing her Maids are young and serve for hire,
Which is as much as Gallus doth desire.

div.head: 308. In Dol praegnantem.
div.l: Dol learning Propria quae maribus without Book,
Like Nomen crescent is genitivo doth look.

div.head: 309. Timidos fortuna repellit.
div.l: When Miles the Serving-man my Lady kist,
She knew him not (though scarcely could resist)
For this (quoth he) my Master bid me say; —
How's that (quoth she) and frowning flings away:
Vext to the heart, she took her mark amisse,
And that she should a serving creature kisse.
Why thus it is when fools must make it known,
They come on others businesse, not their own.

div.head: 310. Against a certain —
div.l: For mad-men Bedlam, Bridewell for a Knave,
Choose whether of those two th'adst rather have.

div.head: 311. Loves progresse.
div.l: Loves first approach, delights sweet song doth sing:
But in departure, she woes sting doth bring.

div.head: 312. On old Scylla.
div.l: Scylla is toothlesse, yet, when she was young,
She had both teeth enough, and too much tongue.
What shall I then of toothlesse Scylla say,
But that her tongue hath worn her teeth away?

div.head: 313. On Gallants cloaks.
div.l: Without, plain cloaks; within, plush't: but I doubt
The wearer's worst within, and best without.

div.head: 314. On Banks the Vserer.
div.l: Banks feels no lamenesse on his knotty Gout,
His money travels for him in and out:
• nd though the soundest legs goe every day,
• e toils to be a • Hell as soon as they.

div.head: 315. Pecunia praevalens.
div.l: • ell Tom of Plato's worth or Aristotles;
• ang't, give him wealth enough; let wit stop bottles.

div.head: 316. On the same.
div.l: • om vow'd to beat his boy against the wall,
• nd as he struck he forthwith caught a fall:
• he boy deriding, said, I doe aver,
• 'have done a thing, you cannot stand to sir.

div.head: 317. On Debt.
div.l: To be indebted is a shame men say,
Then 'tis confessing of a shame to pay.

div.head: 318. A forsworn Maid.
div.l: • osa being false and perjur'd, once a friend
• id me contented be, and mark her end:
But yet I care not, let my friend goe fiddle;
• et him mark her end, I'l mark her middle.

div.head: 319. Adversity.
div.l: • ove is maintain'd by wealth, when all is spent,
Adversity then breeds the discontent.

div.head: 320. On Soranzo.
div.l: Soranzo's broad-brim hat I oft compare
To the vast compasse of the heavenly sphere:
Whose center is, his wondrous little wit.

div.head: 321. To a great Guest.
div.l: With other Friends I bid you to my Feast,
Though coming late, yet are you not the least.

div.head: 322. In Cottam.
div.l: Cotta when he hath din'd saith, God be praisd,
Yet never praiseth God for meat or drink:
Sith Cotta speaketh, and not practiseth,
He speaketh surely what he doth not think.

div.head: 323. De Corde & Lingua.
div.l: The tongue was once a Servant to the heart,
And what it gave she freely did impart:
But now hypocrisie is grown so strong,
She makes the heart a servant to the tongue.

div.head: 324. On Rumpe.
div.l: Rump is a Turn-spit, yet he seldome can
Steale a swolne sop out of the dripping-pan.

div.head: 325. On Poverty.
div.l: If thou be poor, thou shalt be ever so,
None now do wealth, but on the rich bestow.

div.head: 326. In Ebriosum.
div.l: Fie man (saith she) but I tell Mistrisse Anne,
Her drunken Husband is no drunken man.
For those wits which are overcome with drink,
Are voyd of reason, and are Beasts I think.

div.head: 327. Wills error.
div.l: Will sayes his wife's so fat, she scarce can go,
But she as nimbly answers, Faith Si • no:
Alas good Will, thou art mistaken quite,
For all men know, that she is wondrous light.

div.head: 328. On Rome.
div.l: Hate and debate, Rome through the world hath spread,
Yet Roma, amor is, if backward read:
Then is't not strange, Rome hate should foster? no,
For out of backward love all hate doth grow.

div.head: 329. On Tuck.
div.l: At Post and Paire, or Slam, Tom Tuck would play
This Christmasse, but his want therewith, says nay.

div.head: 330. Some thing no savour.
div.l: All things have savour, though some but small;
Nay, a box on th'eare, hath no smell at all.

div.head: 331. Art, Fortune, and Ignorance.
div.l: When Fortune fell asleep, and hate did blind her,
Art, Fortune lost; and Ignorance did find her:
Sith when, dull Ignorance with Fortunes store,
Hath been inrich'd, and Art hath still been poor.

div.head: 332. On Bibens.
div.l: Bibens to shew his liberality,
Made Lusus drunk; (a noble quality,
And much esteem'd) which Bibens faln would pro ••
To be the signe of his familiar love:
Lusus beware, thou'lt finde him in the end,
Familiar Devil, no familiar friend.

div.head: 333. On Tobacco.
div.l: Things which are common, common men do us •
The better shrt doe common things refuse:
Yet Countries-cloth-breech, & Court-velvet-hose
Puffe both alike Tobacco through the nose.

div.head: 334. On Cupid.
div.l: Cupid no wonder was not cloth'd of old,
For love though naked, seldome e'r is cold.

div.head: 335. On Ebrio.
div.l: See where Don Ebrio, like a Dutchman goes,
Yet drunk with English Ale, one would suppose
That he would shoulder down each door & wall,
But they must stand, or he, poor fool must fall.

div.head: 336. On Love.
div.l: Love hath two divers wings, as lovers say:
Thou following him, with one he flyes away;
With th'other, if thou fly he follows thee:
Therefore the Last, Love, onely use for me.

div.head: 337. On the same.
div.l: Love, as 'tis said, doth work with such strange tools,
That he can make fools wise-men, wise-men fools,
Then happy I, for being nor fool, nor wise,
Love with his toyes and tools I shall despise.

div.head: 338. On a Woman.
div.l: Some the word Woman fetch, though with small skil,
From those that want one to effect their wil
If so, I think that wantons there are none,
For till the world want men, can they want none.

div.head: 339. Ingluviem sequitur fames.
div.l: Curio would feed upon the daintiest fare,
That with the Court or Country might compare:
For what lets Curio that he need to care,
To frolick freely with the proud'st that dare:
But this excesse was such in all things rare,
As he prov'd bankrupt e'r he was aware.

div.head: 340. On Maulsters.
div.l: Such Maulsters as ill measure sell for gain,
Are not meer knaves, but also knaves in grain.

div.head: 341. In Corbum.
div.l: Corbus will not, perswade him all I can,
The world should take him for a Gentleman:
His reason's this, because men should not deem,
That he is such as he doth never seem.

div.head: 342. On Priscus Mistresse.
div.l: Priscus commends his Mistris for a Girle,
Whose lips be rubies, and whose teeth are pearle▪
Th'had need prove so, or else it will be found,
He payes too door; they cost him many a pound▪

div.head: 343. On Women.
div.l: Women think wo—men far more constant be,
Than we—men, and the letter O we see,
In wo—men, not in we—men, as they say,
Figures earths constant Orbe; we—men say nay
It means the Moon, which proves (none think i • strang •
Women are cōstant, & most true in change.

div.head: 344. On Souldiers.
div.l: Nor faith, nor conscience common soldiers carry▪
Best pay, is right; their hands are mercenary.

div.head: 345. Drusius and Furio.
div.l: Furio would fight with Drusius in the field,
Because the straw, stout Drusius would not yield,
On which their Mistris trod; they both did meet;
Drusius in field fell dead at Furio's feet;
One had the straw, but with it this Greek letter π
The other lost it, pray who had the better?

div.head: 346. On Cupid.
div.l: Love is a Boy, and subject to the rod
Some say, but Lovers say he is a God:
I think that love is neither god nor boy,
But a mad brains imaginary toy.

div.head: 347. On Candidus.
div.l: When I am sick, not else, thou com'st to see me,
Would fortune from both torments still would free me.

div.head: 348. On a Puritan.
div.l: From impure mouths, now many bear the name
Of Puritan, yet merit not the same.
This one shall onely be my Puritan
That is a knave, yet seems an honest man.

div.head: 349. Ostendit hedera vinum.
div.l: A scoffing mate, that past along Cheap-side,
Incontinent a gallant lasse espide;
Whose tempting Breasts (as to the sale laid out)
Incites this youngster thus to 'gin to flout.
Lady (quoth he) is this flesh to be sould?
No Lord (quoth she) for silver nor for gold,
But wherefore aske you? (and there made a stop)
To buy (quoth he) if not shut up your shop.

div.head: 350. Quantum mutatus ab illo!
div.l: Pedes grown proud makes men admire thereat,
Whose baser breeding, should they think not beare it,
Nay, he on cock-horse rides, how like you that?
Tut! Pedes proverb is, Win gold and weare it.
But Pedes you have seen them rise in hast,
That through their pride have broke their neck at last.

div.head: 351. Vpon Lavina.
div.l: Lavina brought to bed, her husband lookes
To know's childs fortune throughout his books,
His neighbours think h'had need search backward rather,
And learn for certain who had been the father.

div.head: 352. Report and Error.
div.l: Error by Error, Tales by Tales, great grow;
As Snow-balls doe, by rowling to and fro.

div.head: 353. In Superbum.
div.l: Rustick Suerbus fine new cloths hath got,
Of Taffata and velvet, fair in sight;
The shew of which hath so bewitcht the sot,
That he thinks Gentlemen to be his right:
But he's deceiv'd; for true that is of old,
An Ape's an Ape, though he wear cloth of gold.

div.head: 354. No truth in Wine.
div.l: Truth is in wine, but none can find it there,
For in your Taverns, men will lye and sweare.

div.head: 355. On Infidus.
div.l: Infidus was so free of Oaths last day,
That he would swear, what e'r he thought to say:
But now such is his chance, whereat he's griev'd
The more he swears, the lesse he is believ'd.

div.head: 356. On Celsus.
div.l: Celsus doth love himself, Celsus is wise,
For now no Rivall e'r can claim his prize.

div.head: 357. On Christmasse Ivy.
div.l: At Christmasse men doe alwayes Ivy get,
And in each corner of the house it set:
But why doe they, then, use that Bacchus weed?
Because they mean, then Bacchus-like to feed.

div.head: 358. Adversity.
div.l: Adversity hurts none, but onely such
Whom whitest fortune dandled has too much.

div.head: 359. On Bacchus.
div.l: Pot-lifting Bacchus to the earth did bend
His knee to drink a health unto his friend:
And there he did so long in liquour pour,
That he lay quite sick-drunk upon the floor.
Judge, was there not a drunkards kindnes shown,
To drink his friend a health, and loose his own?

div.head: 360. Of a fat man.
div.l: He's rich, that hath great in-comes by the year:
Then that great belly'd man is rich, I'l swear:
For sure his belly ne'r so big had bin,
Had he not daily had great commings in.

div.head: 361. A wished Cramp.
div.l: Some have the Cramp in legs, and hands, 'tis told,
I wish't in my wifes tongue, when she doth scold.

div.head: 362. Vindicta vim sequitur.
div.l: Nick being kick'd and spurr'd, pursues the Law,
That doom'd the dammage at twice forty pence.
Which, when the party wch had wrong'd him, saw;
Thought 'twas too great a fine for such offence.
Why then, quoth Nick, if I too much request,
Thou maist at any time kick out the rest.

div.head: 363. On Flaccus.
div.l: Flaccus being young, they said he was a Gull;
Of his simplicity each mouth was full:
And pittying him, they'd say, the foolish Lad
Would surely be deceived, of all he had.
His youth is past, now may they turn him loose;
For why? the gull is grown to be a Goose.

div.head: 364. Per plumas anser.
div.l: See how young Rusus walks in green each day,
As if he ne'r was youthfull until now:
Ere Christmas next, his green Goose will be gray,
And those high burnish'd plumes in's cap wil bow:
But you do wrong him, since his purse is full,
To call him Goose, that is so young a Gull.

div.head: 365. Of Ienkin.
div.l: Ienkin is a rude Clowne, goe tell him so;
What need I tell, what he himself doth know?
Perhaps he doth not, then he is a sot;
For tell me, what knows he that knows it not?

div.head: 365. On Trigg.
div.l: Trigg having turn'd his sute he struts in state,
And tells the world he's now regenerate.

div.head: 366. To Fortune.
div.l: Poets say Fortune's blind, and cannot see,
And therefore to be born withall, if she
Sometimes drops gifts on undeserving wights:
But sure they are deceiv'd; she hath her sight;
Else could it not at all times so fall out,
That fools should have, and wise men go without.

div.head: 367. On Briscus.
div.l: I pray you give Sir Briscus leave to speak,
The Gander loves to hear himself to creak.

div.head: 368. On an English Ape.
div.l: Would you believe, when you this Monsieur see,
That his whole body should speak French, not he?
That he untravell'd should be French so much,
As French men in his company should seem Dutch?
Or hung some Monsieurs picture on the wall;
By which his damne conceiv'd him, cloaths & all?
No, 'tis the new French Taylors motion, made
Dayly to walk th'Exchange, and help the trade.

div.head: 369. Possessions.
div.l: Those possessions short liv'd are
Into the which we come by warre.

div.head: 370. Nulla dies sine linea.
div.l: By ever learning, Solon waxed old,
For time he knew, was better far then gold:
Fortune would give him gold which would decay
But Fortune cannot give him yesterday.

div.head: 371. In Cornutum.
div.l: One told his wife, a Harts-head he had bought,
To hang his hat upon, and home it brought:
To whom his frugall wife, what need • that care?
I hope, sweet-heart, your head your hat can beare.

div.head: 372. On More-dew.
div.l: More-dew the Mercer; with a kind salute,
Would needs intreat my custome for a suite:
Here Sir, quoth he, for Sattins, Velvets call,
What e'r you please, I'l take your word for all.
I thank'd, took, gave my word; say than,
Am I at all indebted to this man?

div.head: 373. Pari jugo dulcis tractus.
div.l: When Caecus had bin wedded now three dayes,
And all his neighbours bad God give him joy,
This strange conclusion with his wife assayes,
