Why til her marriage-day she prov'd so coy:
'Fore God (saith he) 'twas well thou didst not yeild
For doubtless then my purpose was to leave thee.
Oh Sir (quoth she) I once was so beguild,
And thought the next man should not so deceive me.
Now fie upon't (quo • h he) thou breedst my wo.
Why man (quoth she) I speak but quid pro quo.

div.head: 374. On Sims mariage.
div.l: Six months, quoth Sim, a Suiter, and not sped?
I in a sev'n-night did both woo and wed
Who green fruit loves, must take long paines to shake;
Thine was some down-fall, I dare undertake.

div.head: 375. Vpon Sis.
div.l:
Si •
brags sh'hath beauty, and will prove the same:
As how? as thus Sir; 'tis her Puppies name.

div.head: 376. On Clym.
div.l: Clym cals his wife, and reckoning all his neighbors,
Just half of them are Cuckolds, he avers.
Nay sie, quoth she, I would they heard you speak;
You of your self, it seems, no reckoning make.

div.head: 377. On Gut.
div.l: Science puffs up, sayes Gut, when either Pease
Make him thus swell, or windy Cabbages.

div.head: 378. On Womens faults.
div.l: We men in many faults abound,
But two in women can be found:
The worst that from their Sex proceeds,
Is naught in words, and naught in deeds.

div.head: 379. To a Muck-worm.
div.l: Content great riches is, to make which true,
Your Heir would be content to bury you.

div.head: 380. On Law.
div.l: Our Civil Law doth seem a Royall thing,
It hath more titles then the Spanish King:
But yet the Common-Law quite puts it down,
In getting, like the Pope, so many a Crown.

div.head: 381. In Coam.
div.l: A nor ☊ will Coa espy,
Til she ascend up to the corner'd π

div.head: 382. Maids Nay's.
div.l: Mayds Nayes are nothing, they are shy
But to desire what they deny.

div.head: 383. De Ore.
div.l: Os of O, a Mouth, Scaliger doth make;
And from this letter, Mouth his name doth take:
And I had been of Scaligers belief,
But that I look'd in O, and saw no Teeth.

div.head: 384. In Hugonem.
div.l: Though praise, and please, doth Hugo never none,
Yet praise, and please, doth Hugo ever one;
For praise, and please, doth Hugo himselfe alone.

div.head: 385. On Severus.
div.l: Severus is extream in eloquence,
For he creates rare phrase, but rarer sense:
Unto his Serving-man, alias his Boy,
He utters speech exceeding quaint and coy;
Diminutive, and my defective slave,
My pleasures pleasure is, that I must have
My Corps Coverture, and immediately,
T'insconce my person from frigility.
His Man believ's all's Welsh his Master spoke,
Til he rails English, Rogue go fetch my Cloke.

div.head: 386. On Iulias weeping.
div.l: She by the River sate, and sitting there,
She wept, and made it deeper by a teare.

div.head: 387. On a Gallant.
div.l: What Gallant's that, whose Oaths fly through mine ears?
How like a Lord of Pluto's Court he swears!
How Dutchman-like he swallowes down his drink!
How sweet he takes Tobacco til he stink!
How lofty sprighted he disdains a Boor!
How faithfull hearted he is to a —!
How Cock-tail proud he doth himself advance!
How rare his spurs do ring the Morrice-dance!
Now I protest by Mistris Susans Fan,
He and his boy will make a proper man.

div.head: 388. On Vertue, Milla's Maid.
div.l: Saith Aristotle, Vertue ought to be
Communicative of her self & free;
And hath not Vertue, Milla's maid, been so?
Who's grown hereby, as big as she can go.

div.head: 389. On Corydon.
div.l: An home-spun Peasant with his Urine-glasse,
The Doctor ask'd what Country-man he was.
Quoth Corydon, with making legs full low,
Your worship, that, shall by my water know.

div.head: 390. On a Spanish Souldier.
div.l: A Spanish Souldier, sick unto the death,
His Pistol to's Physitian did bequeath.
Who did demand, what should the reason be,
'Bove other things to give him that; (quoth he)
This with your practice joyned, you may kill,
Sir, all alive, and have the world at will.

div.head: 391. Vpon the Asse.
div.l: The Asse a Courtier on a time would be,
And travel'd forrain Nations for to see;
But home returned, fashion he could none,
His main and tail were onely larger grown.

div.head: 392. On Hypocrisie.
div.l: As Venison in a poor mans Kitchin's rare;
So Hypocrites and Usurers in Heaven are.

div.head: 393. Daemonum certamen.
div.l: A Broker and an Usurer contended,
Which in's profession was the most befriended;
And for experience more to have it tride,
A Scrivener must the difference decide,
To whom (quoth he) you like the Fox & Cub,
One shall be Mammon, th'other Belzebub.

div.head: 394. On Love.
div.l: Love's of it selfe too sweet; the b • st of all
Is; when Loves honey has a dash of gall.

div.head: 395. On Man and Woman.
div.l: When Man and Woman dyes, as Poets sung;
His Heart's the last that stirs, of hers the Tongue.

div.head: 396. On Fabullus.
div.l: I ask'd Fabullus, why he had no wife?
(Quoth he) because I'd live a quiet life.

div.head: 397. On Fornus.
div.l: Fornus takes pains, he need not without doubt,
O yes, he labours much. How? with the Gout.

div.head: 398. Quid non ebrietas.
div.l: Rubin reports, his Mistris is a Punk:
Which being told her, was no whit dismaid,
For sure as death (quoth she) the Villains drunk▪
And in that taking, knows not what he said.
'Twas well excus'd, but oft it comes to passe,
That true we find, In vino veritas.

div.head: 399. No Paines, no Gaines.
div.l: If little labour, little are our gaines,
Mans fortunes are according to his pains.

div.head: 400. Infirmis animosus.
div.l: Pontus by no means from his coyn departs,
Z'foot, will you have of men more then their hearts?

div.head: 401. A culina ad curiam.
div.l: Lixa, that long a Serving-groom hath been,
Will now no more the man be known or seen:
And reason good, he hath the place resign'd;
Witnesse his cloak, throughout with Velvet lin'd,
Which by a Paradox comes thus to passe;
The greasie Gull is turn'd a gallant asse.

div.head: 402. Frustra vocaveris heri.
div.l: Dick had but two words to maintain him ever,
And that was Stand, and after stand Deliver.
But Dick's in Newgate, and he fears shall never
Be blest again with that sweet word, Deliver.

div.head: 403. Magnis non est morandum.
div.l: See how Silenus walks accomplished,
With due performance of his fathers page:
Looks back of purpose to be honoured,
And on each slight occasion 'gins to rage;
You, villain, dog, where hath your stay bin such?
Quoth he, the Broker would not lend so much.

div.head: 404. Puduit sua damna referre.
div.l: Such ill successe had Dick at Dice last night,
As he was forc'd, next day, play least in sight:
But if you love him, make thereof no speeches,
He lost his Rapier, Cloak, and Velvet Breeches.

div.head: 405. Ad Lectorem.
div.l: Reader, thou seest how pale these papers look,
While they fear thy hard censure on my Book.

div.head: 406. Nimis docuit consuetudo.
div.l: Old Fucus board is oft replenished,
But nought thereof must be diminished,
Unlesse some worthlesse upper-dish or twain;
The rest for service still again remain.
His man that us'd to bring them in for show,
Leaving a dish upon the bench below,
Was by his Master (much offended) blam'd,
Which he, as brief, with answer quickly fram'd;
T'hath been so often brought afore this day,
As now ch'ad thoft it selfe had known the way.

div.head: 407. Poculo junguntur amici.
div.l: A health, saith Lucas, to his Loves bright ey;
Which not to pledge, were much indignity;
You cannot doe him greater courtesie,
Then to be drunk, and dam'd for company.

div.head: 408. Nullum stimulum ignaris.
div.l: Caecus awake, was tol'd the Sun appear'd,
Which had the darknesse of the morning clear'd:
But Caecus sluggish, thereto makes reply,
The Sun hath further far to goe then I.

div.head: 409. In Richardum.
div.l: At three goe-downs Dick doffs me off a pot,
The English Gutter's Latine for his throat.

div.head: 410. Non penna, sed usus.
div.l: Cajus accounts himself accurst of men,
Onely because his Lady loves him not:
Who, till he taught her, could not hold her pen,
And yet hath since, another Tutor got.
Cajus it seems, Thy skill she did but cheapen,
And means to try him at another weapon.

div.head: 411. An absolute Gallant.
div.l: If you will see true valour here display'd,
Heare Poly-phemus, and be not afraid.
D'ye see me wrong'd, and will ye thus restrain me?
Sir let me go, for by these hilts I'l brain ye.
Shall a base patch with appearance wrong me?
I'l kill the villain, pray do not prolong me.
Call my Tobacco putrified stuffe?
Tell me it stinks? say it is drosse I snuffe!
Sirrah! what are you? why Sir, what would you?
I am a Prentice, and will knock you too:
O are you so? I cry you mercy then,
I am to fight with none but Gentlemen.

div.head: 412. To Momus.
div.l: Momus thou say'st my Verses are but toyes:
'Tis true, yet truth is often spoke by boyes.

div.head: 413. In Dolentem.
div.l: Dolens doth shew his purse, and tell you this,
It is more horrid then a Pest-house is;
For in a Pest-house many mortals enter,
But in his purse one Angel dares not venter.

div.head: 414. Abditio perditio.
div.l: From Mall but merry, men but mirth derive,
For trix 'tis makes her prove demonstrative.

div.head: 415. On a Gallant.
div.l: Sirrah, come hither, boy, take view of me,
My Lady I am purpos'd to goe see;
What doth my Feather flourish with a grace?
And this my curled hair become my face?
How decent doth my Doublet's form appear?
I would I had my Sute in Long-lane here.
Do not my spurs pronounce a silver sound?
Is not my hose-circumference profound?
Sir these be well, but there is one thing ill,
Your Taylor with a sheet of Paper-bill,
Vowes hee'l be paid, and Sergeants he hath fee'd,
Which wait your coming forth to do the deed.
Boy God-a-mercy, let my Lady stay,
I'll see no Counter for her sake to day.

div.head: 416. In Sextum.
div.l: Sextus six pockets wears, two for his uses,
The other four to pocket up abuses.

div.head: 417. A Stammerer.
div.l: Balbus with other men would angry be,
Because they could not speak as well as he;
For others speak but with their mouth he knows,
But Balbus speaks both through the mouth & nose.

div.head: 418. On himselfe.
div.l: I dislikt but even now;
Now I love I know not how.
Was I idle, and that while
Was I fired with a smile?
Ile to work, or pray, and then
I shall quite dislike agen.

div.head: 419. Tom's fortune.
div.l: Tom tel's he's rob'd, and counting all his losses,
Concludes, all's gone, the world is full of crosses:
If all be gone, Tom take this comfort then,
Th'art certain never to have crosse agen.

div.head: 420. Opus and Vsus.
div.l: Opus for need consum'd his wealth apace,
And ne'r would cease untill he was undone;
His brother Vsus liv'd in better case
Than Opus did, although the eldest son.
'Tis strange it should be so, yet here was it,
Opus had all the Land, Vsus the Wit.

div.head: 421. A good Wife.
div.l: A Batchelor would have a Wife were wise,
Fair, rich, and young, a maiden for his bed —
Nor proud, nor churlish, but of faultlesse size;
A Country houswife in the City bred.
But he's a fool, and long in vain hath staid;
He should bespeak her, there's none ready made.

div.head: 422. Anger.
div.l: But heard with anger, we confesse the crime.

div.head: 423. Vpon Gellia.
div.l: When Gellia went to school, and was a Girle;
Her teeth for whitenes might compare with pearle
But after she the taste of sweet meats knew,
They turn'd all Opals, to a perfect blew;
Now Gellia takes Tobacco, what should let,
But last they should converted be to jet?

div.head: 424. On an unconstant Mistresse.
div.l: I dare not much say when I thee commend,
Lest thou be changed e'r my praises end.

div.head: 425. In Lesbiam.
div.l: Why should I love thee Lesbia? I no reason see:
Then out of reason, Lesbia, I love thee.

div.head: 426. In Paulinum.
div.l: Paul by day wrongs me, yet he daily swears,
He wisheth me as well as to his soul:
I know his drift to damn that he nought cares,
To please his body, therefore good friend Paul,
If thy kinde nature will afford me grace,
Hereafter love me in thy body's place.

div.head: 427. On Zeno.
div.l: Zeno would fain th'old widow Egle have;
Trust me he's wise, for she is rich and brave:
But Zeno, Zeno, she will none of you;
In my mind she's the wiser of the two.

div.head: 428. Of a Drunkard.
div.l: Cinna one time most wonderfully swore,
That whilst he breath'd he would drink no more▪
But since I know his meaning, for I think
He meant he would not breath whilst he did drink.

div.head: 429. To Cotta.
div.l: Be not wroth Cotta, that I not salute thee,
I us'd it whilst I worthy did repute thee;
Now thou art made a painted Saint, and I,
Cotta, will not commit Idolatry.

div.head: 430. To Women.
div.l: Ye that have beauty, and withall no pitty,
Are like a prick-song lesson without ditty

div.head: 431. On Creta.
div.l: Creta doth love her husband wondrous well,
It needs no proof, for every one can tell:
So strong's her love, that if I not mistake,
It doth extend to others for his sake.

div.head: 432. On Priscus.
div.l: Why still doth Priscus strive to have the wall?
Because he's often drunk and fears to fall.

div.head: 433. On Rufus.
div.l: At all, quoth Rufus, lay you what you dare,
I'l throw at all, and 'twere a peck of gold;
No life lies on't, then coyn I'l never spare;
Why Rufus, that's the cause of all that's sold?
For with frank Gamesters it doth oft befall,
They throw at all, till thrown quite out of all.

div.head: 434. On Tobacco.
div.l: Tobacco is a weed of so great pow'r,
That it (like earth) doth all it feeds, devour.

div.head: 435. Vpon Nasuto.
div.l: When at the Table once I did averre,
Well-taken discord, best did please the ear,
And would be judg'd by any Q • irister,
Were in the Chappel, Pauls, or Westminster;
Nasuto sitting at the nether end,
(First having drunk and cough'd) quoth he my friend,
If that were true, my wife and I, I feare,
Should soon be sent to some Cathedral Q • ire.

div.head: 436. Nec vultus indicat virum.
div.l: Dick in a raging deep discourtesy,
Calls an Atturny meer Necessity:
The more knave he; admit he had no Law,
Must he be flouted at by every Daw?

div.head: 437. On Furius.
div.l: Furius a lover was, and had loving fits,
He lov'd so madly that he lost his wits;
Yet he lost nought, yet grant I, he was mad,
How could he lose that which he never had?

div.head: 438. Fools Fortune.
div.l: Fools have great fortune, but yet not all,
For some are great fools, whose fortune's small.

div.head: 439. Tace sed age.
div.l: Little or nothing said, soon mended is,
But they that nothing do, do most amisse.

div.head: 440. On Count-surly.
div.l: Count-surly will no Scholler entertain:
Or any wiser then himself; how so?
The reason is, when fools are in his train,
His wit amongst them, makes a goodly show.

div.head: 441. On Women.
div.l: When man lay dead-like, woman took her life,
From a crook't embleme of her nuptiall strife;
And hence (a • bones would be at rest) her ease
She loves so well, and is so hard to please.

div.head: 442. Verses.
div.l: Who will not honour noble Numbers, when
Verses out-live the bravest deeds of men?

div.head: 443. Poor Irus.
div.l: Irus using to lye upon the ground,
One morning under him a feather found,
Have I all night here lien so hard (quoth he)
Having but one poor feather under me:
I wonder much then how they take their ease,
That night by night, lie on a bed of these.

div.head: 444. Merry Doll.
div.l: I blame not lusty Doll, that strives so much,
To keep her light heart free from sorrowes touch;
Shee'l dance and sing a hem boyes, hey all six,
She's steel to th'back, all mirth, all meretrix.

div.head: 445. Heaven and Hell.
div.l: I • Heaven's call'd the place where Angels dwell,
My purse wants Angels, pray call that Hell.

div.head: 446. Like qu • stion like answer.
div.l: A young beginner walking through Cheap-side,
A house shut up he presently espy'd
And read the Bill, which o'r the door was set,
Which said, the house and shop was to be let;
That known, he ask'd a young man presently,
Which at the next door stood demurely.
May not this shop be let alone? qoth he,
Yes, you may let't alone for ought I see.

div.head: 447. On deaf Ioan.
div.l: She prates to others, yet can nothing heare,
Just like a sounding Jugge that wants an eare.

div.head: 448. Of an ill wife.
div.l: Priscus was weeping when his wife did dye,
Yet he was then in better case then I:
I should be merry, and should think to thrive,
Had I but his dead wife for mine alive.

div.head: 449. Meum & Tuum.
div.l: Megge lets her husband boast of rule and riches,
But she rules all the roast, and wears the breeches.

div.head: 450. Deaths trade.
div.l: Death is a Fisherman, the world we see
His Fish-pond is, and we the Fishes be.
He sometimes, Angler-like, doth with us play,
And slily takes us one by one away;
Diseases are the murthering-books, which he
Doth catch us with, the bait mortality,
Which we poor silly fish devour, til strook,
At last too late we feel the bitter hook.
At other times he brings his net, and then
At once sweeps up whole Cities ful of men,
Drawing up thousands at a draught, and saves
Onely some few, to make the others graves:
His Net some raging pestilence; now he
Is not so kind as other Fishers be;
For if they take one of the smaller • rye,
They throw him in again, he shall not dye:
But death is sure to kill all he can get,
And all is Fish with him that comes to Net.

div.head: 451. O • Bice.
div.l: Bice laughs when no man speak • , and doth protest
It is his own breech there that break • the jest.

div.head: 452. Valiant in drinke.
div.l: Who onely in his Cups will • ight, is like
A clock that must be oil'd wel ere it strike.

div.head: 453. Master and Scholler.
div.l: A Pedant ask'd a Puny ripe and bold,
In an hard frost, the Latine word for cold:
I'l tell you out of hand, (quoth he) for lo,
I have it at my fingers ends, you know.

div.head: 454. Gasters great belly.
div.l: Gaster did seem to me to want his eyes,
For he could neither see his legs nor thighs;
But yet it was not so; he had his sight,
Onely his belly hanged in his light.

div.head: 455. Drunken Dick.
div.l: When Dick for want of drunken mates grows sick,
Then with himself to work goes faithfull Dick.
The buttery dore t'himself he shutteth close
That done, then goes the pot straight wayes to's nose:
A health (quoth noble Dick) each hogs-head than
Must seeming pledge this honest faithfull man:
But straight from kindnes Dick to humors grows,
And then to th'barrels he his valour shows,
Throwing about the cups, the pots, the glasses,
And rails at the tuns, calling them drunken asses:
Ne'r ceasing this same faithfull coyl to keep,
Till under th'hogshead Dick fals fast asleep.

div.head: 456. In Sextinum.
div.l: A pretty block Sextinus names his Hat,
So much the fitter for his head by that.

div.head: 457. Sine sanguine.
div.l: Ralph challeng'd Robin, time and place appointed,
Their Parents heard on't, O how they lamented!
But good luck was, they soon were freed of fear,
The one ne'r meant, the other came not there.

div.head: 458. On humane Bodies.
div.l: Our bodies are like shooes, which off we cast,
Physick their Cobler is, and death the Last.

div.head: 459. On Trencherman.
div.l: Tom shifts the Trenchers, yet he never can,
Endure that luke-warm name of Servingman;
Serve or not serve, let Tom doe what he can,
He is a serving, who's a Trencher-man.

div.head: 460. A Toothlesse-pratler.
div.l: Nature the teeth doth as an hedge ordain,
The nimble frisking tongue for to contain:
No marvel then since that the hedge is out,
If Fuscus tongue walketh so fast about.

div.head: 461. A musicall Lady.
div.l: A Lady fairer far then fortunate,
(In dancing) thus o'r-shot her self of late,
The Musick not in tune, pleasd not her mind,
For which he with the Fidlers fault did find;
Fidlers (quoth she) your Fiddles tune for shame▪
But as she was a speaking of the same,
To mend the consort, let she did a (F.)
Whereas the fidling knaves thus did her greet,
Madam your pipe's in tune, it plays most sweet;
Strike up, qd. they, (but then the knaves did smile)
And as you p • p • , wee'l dance another while.
At which, away the blushing Lady flings,
But as she goes, her former notes she sings.

div.head: 462. In Laurettam.
div.l: Lauretta is laid o'r, how I'l not say,
And yet I think two manner of wayes I may,
Doubly laid o'r, videlicet, her face,
Laid o'r with colours, and her coat with lace.

div.head: 463. On Macer.
div.l: You call my verses toy's, th'are so, 'tis true,
Yet they are better then ought comes from you.

div.head: 464. Briskap the Gallant.
div.l: Though thou hast little judgement in thy head,
More than to dresse thee, drink and goe to bed;
Yet may'st thou take the wall, & th'way shalt lead,
Sith Logick wills that simple things precede.

div.head: 465. Necessity hath no Law.
div.l: Florus did beat his Cook, and 'gan to sweaee,
Because his meat was rotten roasted there.
Peace good Sir (quoth the Cook) Need hath no Law,
'Tis rotten roasted, 'cause 'twas rotten raw.

div.head: 466. In Carientium.
div.l: Garentius might have wedded where he woo'd,
But he was poor, his means was nothing good,
'Twas but for lack of living that he lost her;
For why? no penny now, no Pater noster.

div.head: 467. On Harpax.
div.l: Harpax gave to the poor all by his will,
Because his heir should not faign'd tears distill.

div.head: 468. To a Barber.
div.l: Tonsorius onely lives by cutting haire,
And yet he brags that Kings to him sit bare:
Me thinks he should not brag and boast of it,
For he must stand to beggars while they sit.

div.head: 469. Vpon Grand • orto.
div.l: The morrow after just Saint Georges day,
Grand • orto piteous drunk, sate in a ditch,
His hands by's side, his gelding stray'd away,
His scarlet hose, and doublet very rich;
With mud and mire all beastly raid, and by
His feather with his close-stool-hat did ly.
We ask'd the reason of his sitting there,
Zounds 'cause I am King Solomon (quoth he)
And in my Throne; then for the Love we beare,
(Replyed my selfe) unto your Majesty,
Wee'l pull you out, & henceforth wish your grace
Would speak your Proverbs in a warmer place.

div.head: 470. The Fencer and Physick Doctor.
div.l: Lie thus (the Fencer cryes) thus must you guard,
Thus must you slip, thus point, thus pass, thus ward
And if you kill him Sir, this trick learn then
With this same trick you may kill many men.
A Doctor standing by, cryes, Fencing fool,
Both you & he to me may come to school,
Thou dost but prate: my deeds shall show my skil
Where thou hurt'st one, an hundred I doe kill.

div.head: 471. In Lusiam.
div.l: Lusia who scorns all others imitations,
Cannot abide to be out-gone in fashions:
She sayes she cannot have a hat or ruffe,
A gown, a peticoat, a band, or cuffe.
But that these Citizens (whom she doth hate)
Will get into't, at ne'r so dear a rate:
But Lusia now doth such a fashion wear,
Whose hair is curl'd, and costs her som what dear:
That there's no Citizen, what e'r she be,
Can be transform'd so like an Owl as she.

div.head: 472. Kisses.
div.l: Give the food that satisfies a Guest:
Kisses are but dry banquets to a feast

div.head: 473. A Civilian.
div.l: A lusty old grown-grave gray-headed Sire,
Stole to a wench, to quench his lusts desire;
She ask'd him what profession he might be?
I am a Civil Lawyer, Girle, (quoth he)
A Civil Lawyer Sir! you make me muse,
Your talk's too broad for Civil men to use;
If Civil Lawyers are such bawdy men,
Oh what (quoth she) are other Lawyers then?

div.head: 474. Rainaldo, and Rainer.
div.l: Rainaldo meeting Reiner in the street,
Deep in his debt, he doth thus Reiner greet,
You know some money is betwixt us two,
That well-nigh now these ten years hath bin due;
Quoth Reiner (looking down unto his feet)
I' • aith and we will part it, if I see't:
But as I live Rainaldo I find none,
As fain as you, I would you had your owne.

div.head: 475. Spinus his choyce.
div.l: Spinus would wed, but he would have a wench
That hath all tongues, Italian, Spanish, French,
But I disswade him; for if she hath any,
She hath enough; if two, she hath too too many.

div.head: 476. Backbiters.
div.l: When Codrus catches fleas, what e'r he ailes,
He kils them with his teeth, not his nails;
Saying, that man by man may blamelesse go,
If every one would use Backbiters so.

div.head: 477. In Salonus.
div.l: Oft in the night Salonus is inclin'd,
To rise and pisse; and doth as oft break wind▪
If's Urinall be glasse, as 'tis no doubt,
I wonder it so many cracks holds out.

div.head: 478. In Leonatum.
div.l: The filthiest, the fowlest, deformedst lasse,
That is, will be, I think or ever was,
Leonatus loves; wherewith should she him draw,
Except as she's like jet, he be like straw?

div.head: 479. Nosce teipsum.
div.l: Walking and meeting one not long ago,
I ask't who 'twas, he said he did not know:
I said, I know thee; so said he, I you,
But he that knows himselfe I never knew.

div.head: 480. An Old Silvium.
div.l: Silvius by Simony a living got,
And he liv'd well upon it; pray why not?
For he the poor did pill, the rich did lurch,
And so became a pillar of the Church.

div.head: 481. On Perfumes.
div.l: They that smel least, smell best: which intimates,
They smell like Beasts that smell like Civet Cats.

div.head: 482. Arcades ambo.
div.l: Iack and Dick both with one woman dealt
So long till she the pains of woman felt:
Now Dick he thinks to put a trick on Iack
And Iack again to hang it on Dicks back:
Which got the Child, it seems a double case,
I • hath so like (they say) Iacks nose, Dicks face.
But by both marks my judgement should be quick,
Et vitulo tu dignus Iack & Dick.

div.head: 483. On Punchin.
div.l: Give me a reason why men call
Punchin a dry plant-Animall.
Because as plants by water grow,
Punchin by Beer & Ale spreads so.

div.head: 484. Ne fide colori.
div.l: When Bassa walks abroad she paints her face,
And then she would be seen in every place,
For then your Gallants who so e'r they are,
Under a colour will account her faire.

div.head: 485. In Flavium.
div.l: When Flavius once would needs praise Tin,
But what his belly did bethink,
Platters for meat, and Pots for drink.

div.head: 486. Ad Quintum.
div.l: Thy lawfull wife, fair Lelia needs must be,
For she was forc'd by Law to marry thee.

div.head: 487. In Virtutem.
div.l: Vertue we praise, but practice not her good,
(Athenian-like) we act not what we know▪
So many men doe talk of Robin-Hood,
Who never yet shot arrow in his bow.

div.head: 488. A good wits diet.
div.l: That which upholds our tottering walls of flesh,
Is food: and that which doth our wits refresh,
Is wholsome study: for like longer fare,
Be solid Arts, but sweet meats Poems are.

div.head: 489. On Womens tongue.
div.l: Things that be bitter, bitterer than gall,
Physitians say, are alwayes Physicall.
Then womens tongues, if into powder beaten,
And in a Potion, or a pill be eaten,
Nothing more bitter is, I therefore muse,
That womens tongues in Physick they ne'r use:
There's many men who live unquiet lives,
Would spare that bitter member of their wives.
Then prove them Doctor, use them in a pill;
Things oft help sick men, that do sound men kill.

div.head: 490. A proper comparison.
div.l: As there are three blue beans in a blue bladder,
As there are thrice three rounds in a long ladder,
As there are three nooks in a corner'd cap,
And three corners and one in a Map,
Even so like all these,
There are three Universities.

div.head: 491. Of Death.
div.l: He that fears death, or mourns it in the just,
Shews of the resurrection little trust.

div.head: 492. Woman.
div.l: Woman was once a rib, (as truth hath said)
Else sith her tongue runs wide from every point,
I should have dream'd her substance had bin made
Of Adams whirle-bone, when 'twas out of joynt.

div.head: 493. Pepertit, &c.
div.l: Nels Husband said, she brought him nought but toys,
But yet (without his help) she brings him boys.

div.head: 494. Insipiens.
div.l: Two friends discoursing that together stood,
The one enquiring if the other could
Tell whether such a man were wise?
He answer'd no, but he is otherwise.

div.head: 495. Romes wifelesse Clergy.
div.l: Long did I wonder, and I wonder'd much,
Rome should her Clergy that contentment grudge
As to debar them of their proper due;
What, doth she all with continence indue?
O no; they find a womans lips so dainty,
They'l tye themselves from one, 'cause they'l have twenty.

div.head: 496. On Eves Apples.
div.l: Eve for thy fruit thou gav'st too dear a price,
What? for an Apple give a Paradise?
If now adayes of fruit such gaines were made,
A Coster-monger were a Devilish trade.
Will the Perfumer met me in the street,
I stood amaz'd, he ask'd me what I meant;
In faith, said I, your Gloves are very sweet,
And yet your breath doth cast a stronger sent:

div.head: 498. Beauty.
div.l: Beauty's no other but a lovely grace,
Of lively colours, flowing from the face.

div.head: 499. On Poeticall Blinks.
div.l: He nine wayes looks, and needs must learned be,
That all the Muses at one view can see.

div.head: 500. A Conceit.
div.l: As Sextus once was opening of a Nut,
With a sharpe knife his finger deeply cut,
What signe is this, quoth he, can any tell?
'Tis sign, quoth one, y'have cut your finger well.
Not so, saith he, for now my finger's sore,
And I am sure that it was well before.

div.head: 501. Women.
div.l: Howsoe'r they be, thus doe they seem to me,
They be and seem not, seem what least they be:

div.head: 502. Mutuans Dissimulans.
div.l: Dick crafty borrows to no other end,
But that he will not ought to others lend,
That else might ask him: 'Tis some wisedome Dick
How ere, accounted but a knavish trick.

div.head: 503. Writing.
div.l: When words we want, love teacheth to indite;
And what we blush to speak, she bids us write.

div.head: 504. A cure for Impatience.
div.l: Who would be patient, wait he at the Pool,
For Bull-heads, or for Block-heads in the School.

div.head: 505. Satisfaction.
div.l: For all our works, a recompence is sure:
'Tis sweet to think on what was hard t'endure.

div.head: 506. To Mistris mutable.
div.l: Love runs within your veins, as it were mixt
With Quick-silver, but would be wisely fixt:
For though you may for beauty bear the Bell,
Yet ever to ring Changes sounds not well.

div.head: 507. On a Mad-man.
div.l: One ask'd a man-man, if a wife he had?
A wife! quoth he, I never was so mad.

div.head: 508. To Scilla.
div.l: If it be true that promise be a debt,
Then Scilla will her freedom hardly get;
For if she hath vow'd her service to so many,
She'l neither pay them all, nor part from any.
Yet she to satisfie her debts, desires
To yeeld her body, as the Law requires.

div.head: 509. Nescis, quid serus vesper vehat.
div.l: Lyn • us deviseth as he lyes in bed,
What new apparrell he were best to make him:
So many fashions flow within his head,
As much he fears the Taylor will mistake him:
But he mistook him not, that by the way
Did for his old suit lay him up that day.

div.head: 510. To Ficus.
div.l: Ficus hath lost his nose, but knows not how,
And that seems strange to ev'ry one that knows it:
Me thinks I see it written in his brow,
How, wherefore, and the cause that he did loose it.
To tell you true, Ficus, I thus suppose,
'Twas some French Caniball bit off your nose.

div.head: 511. On a painted Curtezan.
div.l: Whosoever saith thou sellest all, doth jest,
Thou buy'st thy beauty, that sels all the rest

div.head: 512. Of Arnaldo.
div.l: Arnaldo free from fault, demands his wife,
Why he is burthen'd with her wicked life?
Quoth she, good husband doe not now repent,
I far more burthens bear, yet am content.

div.head: 513. Labor improbus omnia vincit.
div.l: Glogo will needs be knighted for his lands,
Got by the labour of his fathers hands,
And hopes to prove a Gentleman of note,
For he hath bought himself a painted coat.

div.head: 514. Quis nisi mentis inops—
div.l: Ware proffer'd stinks; yet stay good Proverb, stay,
Thou art deceiv'd, as Clients best can say;
Who proferring trebble fees, for single care,
It's well accepted, gold it is such ware.

div.head: 515. On a friend indeed.
div.l: A reall friend a Cannon cannot batter;
With nom'nall friends, a Squib's a perilous matter,

div.head: 516. On an Italian Proverb.
div.l: Three women met upon the Market day,
Do make a Market, (they do use to say
In Italy) and why? their tongues do walk
As loud, as if an hundred men did talk.
One hearing this, swore had his wife been there
And made a fourth, there might have been a Faire.

div.head: 517. Mans ingresse and egresse.
div.l: Nature, which head-long into life did throng us,
With our feet forwards to our grave doth bring us
What is lesse ours, then this our borrow'd breath?
We stumble into life, we goe to death.

div.head: 518. On bad Debtors.
div.l: Bad debtors are good lyers; for they say,
I'l pay you without faile, on such a day;
Come is the day, to come the debt is still,
So still they lye, though stand in debt they will.
But Fulcus hath so oft ly'd in this wise,
That now he lyes in Ludgate for his lyes.

div.head: 519. On a Iustasse.
div.l: A Iustice walking o'r the frozen Thames,
The Ice about him round, began to crack;
He said to's man, here is some danger, Iames,
I pray thee help me over on thy back.

div.head: 520. Genitoris nesciens.
div.l: Tom asks no fathers blessing, if you note him,
And wiser he, unlesse he knew who got him.

div.head: 521. To a sleeping Talker.
div.l: In sleep thou talk'st un-forethought mysteries,
And utter'st un-foreseen things, with close eyes.
How wel wouldst thou discourse if thou wert dead
Since sleep, deaths image, such fine talk hath bred?

div.head: 522. Omne simile non est idem.
div.l: Together as we walk'd, a friend of mine
Mistook a painted Madam for a Signe,
That in a window stood; but I acquainted,
Told him it was no wooden sign was painted,
But Madam Meretrix: yea, true, said he,
Yet 'tis a little signe of modesty.

div.head: 523. Tandem manifestum.
div.l: Katharine that hid those Candles out of sight,
May well conceive they'l come at length to light.

div.head: 524. Qui ebrius laudat temperantiam.
div.l: Severus likes not these unseason'd lines
Of rude absurdities, times foul abuse,
To all posterities, and their assignes,
That might have been (saith he) to better use.
What senslesse gull, but reason may convince,
Or jade so dull, but being kick'd will wince?

div.head: 525. Quantum mutatus ab illo.
div.l: Would any deem Manasses now the man,
That whilome was not worth a wooden kan.
Doubtlesse the Dunce in something doth surpasse,
Yet his red nose is still the same it was.

div.head: 526. On wisedome and vertue.
div.l: Wise-men are wiser than good-men, what then?
'Tis better to be wiser than wise men.

div.head: 527. On Ducus.
div.l: Ducus keeps house, and it with reason stands,
That he keep house, hath sold away his lands.

div.head: 528. Mysus and Mopsa.
div.l: Mysus and Mopsa hardly could agree,
Striving about superiority:
The Text which saith that man and wife are one,
Was the chief Argument they stood upon.
She held, they both one woman should become:
He held, they should be man, and both but one.
So they contended daily, but the strife
Could not be ended, till both were one wife.

div.head: 529. On Photinus.
div.l: I met Photinus at the B— Court,
Cited (as he said) by a Knave relator:
I ask'd him, wherefore? he in laughing sort,
Told me it was but for a Childish matter.
How e're he laught it out, he lied not;
Indeed 'twas childish, for the child he got.

div.head: 530. On Castriotes.
div.l: See, see, what love is now betwixt each fist,
Since Castriotes had a scabby wrist:
How kindly they, by clawing one another,
As if the left hand were the right hands brother!

div.head: 531. New Rhetorique.
div.l: Good Arguments without coyn, will not stick;
To pay, and not to say, 's best Rhetorick.

div.head: 532. To some kinde Readers.
div.l: This Book of mine I liken to a glasse,
Wherein the fool may look and laugh his fill:
He having done with't Readers, as ye passe,
Here take and use it, as long as you will.

div.head: 533. Est mihi Divi parens.
div.l: Owinus wondreth, since he came from Wales,
What the description of this Isle might be;
That ne'r had seen but mountaines, hils, and dales,
Yet would he stand and boast on's pedegree.
From Rice ap Richard, sprung from Dick a Cow,
Be cot, was right good gentleman, law ye now?

div.head: 434. Principia sordida.
div.l: Bassus hath Lands good store, and leases Farms,
Whose Mother, Milk-pails bore, e'r he bore arms.

div.head: 535. On Thirsites.
div.l: Although Thirsites have a filthy face,
And staring eyes, and little outward grace:
Yet this he hath, to make amends for all,
Nature her selfe, is not more naturall.

div.head: 536. On Zoilus.
div.l: If Souldiers may obtain four Terms of war,
Muskets should be the pleaders, Pikes the bar;
For black bags, Bandeliers, Jackets for gowns,
Angels for fees, we'll take no more crackt crowns.

div.head: 537. On a long beard.
div.l: Thy beard is long, better it would thee fit,
To have a shorter beard, and longer wit.

div.head: 538. On my selfe.
div.l: Who seeks to please all men each way,
And not himselfe offend;
He may begin to work to day,
But God knows when hee'l end.

div.head: 539. Nimium ne crede colori.
div.l: Battas believed for a simple truth,
That yonder gilt-spur spruce and Velvet youth,
Was some great personage, or worthy weight,
Untill one told him he was but a Knight.
A Knaight (quoth Battas) vaith I chud a zworne,
A hod not bin lass then zome Gen-man borne.

div.head: 540. Silens simplex.
div.l: Will would seem wise, and many words let passe,
Speaking but little 'cause he's such an —

div.head: 541. To the mis-interpreter.
div.l: Cease gaul'd back guilt, these inscious lines to mince,
The world wil know y'are rub'd if once ye wince;
They hem within their seeming Critique wall,
Particularly none; generally all:
'Mongst which if you have chanc'd to catch a prick
Cry we-hy if you will, but doe not kick.

div.head: 542. To Mary Meare.
div.l: Meare, since unmixt, unmary'd, and a maid;
Then you to be a Mearmaid may be said:
A Mearmaid's flesh above, and fish below,
And so may you be too, for ought I know.

div.head: 543. Ad Rinaldum amic.
div.l: See, see, Rinaldus! Prethee who is that,
That wears you great green feather in his Hat,
Like to some Tilter? sure it is some Knight,
Whose wits being green, his head must needs be light.

div.head: 544. On himselfe.
div.l: Mirth pleaseth some, to others 'tis offence,
Some commend plain conceit, some profound sence;
Some wish a witty jest, some dislike that,
And most would have themselves, they know not what.
Then he that would please all, and himself too,
Takes more in hand then he is like to doe.

div.head: 545. Fingers end.
div.l: Philomathes once studying to indite,
Nibled his fingers, and his nailes did bite:
By this I know not what he did intend,
Unlesse his wit lay at his fingers end.

div.head: 546. Sapia qui vendit oportet.
div.l: Ianus doth jesting, use Equivocation,
Which he alludes as doubtfull words of Art,
To hide the colour of his Occupation,
But to the Devil he bears an honest heart.

div.head: 547. Clamans Asinus.
div.l: Who says Tom Tipstaffe is no man of calling?
Can any Cryer at Sessions be more bawling?

div.head: 548. Vpon Dunmo.
div.l: I Dunmo ask'd as we at Supper sate,
How long he had liv'd in the maried state,
Sir, just (quoth Dunmo) with my wife I met
In the great Plague time, I remember yet,
And sighing, as he would have burst in twain,
Said, now almost the thirtieth of her raign.

div.head: 549. Vpon Tom Tolthams Nose.
div.l: The radiant colour of Tom Toltham's nose,
Puts down the Lilly, and obscures the Rose;
Had I a Jewell of such precious hew,
I would present it to some Monarch's view,
No subject should possesse such Jems as those,
Ergo, the King must have Tom Toltham's nose.

div.head: 550. Domina praedominans.
div.l: Ill may Rodolphos boast of rule or riches,
That lets his wife rule him, and wear the breeches:

div.head: 551. Titus the Gallant.
div.l: Brave Titus three years in the Town hath been,
Yet not the Lyons, nor the Tombs hath seen;
I cannot tell the cause without a smile,
He hath bin in the Counter all this while.

div.head: 552. In Lalum.
div.l: Lalus which loves to hear himselfe discourse,
Talks to himselfe as if he frantick were,
And though himself might no where hear a wors • ,
Yet he no other but himselfe will heare;
Stop not his mouth if he be troublesome,
But stop his ears, and then the man is dumbe.

div.head: 553. To Criticus.
div.l: Criticus about to kisse a Mayden throng,
He hapned first on one whose nose was long;
He flouting, said, I fain would kisse you Sweet,
But that I fear our lips will never meet,
Your nose stands out so far; the Maiden dy'd
Her cheeks with Crimson, but soon thus reply'd,
Pray sir, then kisse me in that place where I
To hinder you, have neither nose nor eye.

div.head: 554. Profundo Scientia.
div.l: Sal can by silence, deep profundity,
Force you cry, fough! Ieronimo go by.

div.head: 555. On two by Sea.
div.l: Two Youngsters going by Sea, th'one
That ne'r before had been the Sea upon.
Casts up; and as he heaves, he Bo doth cry;
O said the other, Sir, y'are sick, ye'll dy.
No (says the Sea-sick) though my stomack's loose,
You see, I can cry Bo unto a Goose.

div.head: 556. Vt pluma parsona.
div.l: Why wears Laurentius such a lofty feather?
Because he's proud, and foolish both together.

div.head: 557. Aurum volat ocius Euro.
div.l: Monsieur Flemingo fraught with Angels store,
Would see fair London, never seen before:
Where lodging with his Mistress but one night,
Had (ere he parted) put them all to flight.

div.head: 558. To Pontilianus.
div.l: Dogs on their Masters fawn and leap,
And wag their tails apace;
So, though the Flatt'rer want a taile,
His tongue supplies the place.

div.head: 559. Instabilis stans.
div.l: Mat being drunken, much his anger wreaks
On's wife; but stands to nothing that he speaks.

div.head: 560. On some Lawyers.
div.l: Law serves to keep disordered men in aw,
But Aw preserves orders, and keeps the Law,
Were Aw away L[aw]yers would lyers be
For Lucre; which they have and hold in fee.

div.head: 561. Health.
div.l: Even from my heart, much Health I wish,
No Health I'll wash with drink,
Health wish'd, not wash'd, in words, not wine,
To be the best I think.

div.head: 562. Case is altered.
div.l: Tom Case (some do report) was lately haltered;
If this be true, why then the case is altered.

div.head: 563. Quae placuit Domino nupta est Ancilla sodali.
div.l: Madam Rugosa knows not were to find
One Chamber-maid of ten to please her mind.
But yet my Lor • so likes their comely carriage,
As he prefers them to his men in marriage.

div.head: 564. Plagis mitior.
div.l: Katharine that grew so curst, and fit for no man,
With beating soon became a gentle-woman.

div.head: 565. Priscus.
div.l: When Priscus raisd from low to high estate,
Rode through the street in pompous jollity;
Cajus his poor familiar friend of late,
Bespake him thus, Sir now you know not me;
'Tis likely friend (quoth Priscus) to be so,
For at this time my selfe I doe not know.

div.head: 566. Anger soon appeased.
div.l: When Iohn Cornutus doth his wife reprove,
For being false and faithlesse in her love,
His wife to smooth those wrinkles in his brow,
Doth stop his mouth with, Iohn come kisse me now.

div.head: 567. A foole for Company.
div.l: Fatuus will drink with no such Asse,
That lets his jests (unapprehended) passe:
Or if he jest with such of shallow brain,
He laughs himselfe to make his jests more plain.
Thus Fatuus doth jest and play • he sany,
To laugh at's self, hee's fool if there be any.

div.head: 568. In Cineam.
div.l: When Cineas comes amongst his friends in mourning,
He slily notes, who first his cap doth move;
Him he salutes, the rest so grimly scorning,
As if for ever he had lost his love;
I knowing how the humor it did fit
Of the fond Gull to be saluted first,
Catch at my Cap, but move it not a whit,
Which he perceiving, seems with spight to burst.
But Cineas, why expect you more of me▪
Then I of you? I am as good a man,
And better too by many a quality:
For vault, and dance, and fence, and rime I can:
You keep a whore at your own charge, men tell me,
Indeed friend Cineas, therein you excell we.

div.head: 569. On Captain Sharke.
div.l: One ask'd a friend where Captain Shark did lye,
Why sir (quoth he) at ADIV2ate, at the Pye;
Away, quoth th'other, he lies not there I know't,
No, sayes the other, then he lies in's throat.

div.head: 570. A witty answer.
div.l: A lean, yet • at Recusant being confin'd
Unto a Justice house, whose wife was great,
(Not great with child, but hugely great wth meat)
At supper thus began to grope his mind,
To hoc est corpus what say you? she sed;
Marry (quoth he) I say it is well feed.

div.head: 571. Gossips discourse.
div.l: When Gillian and her Gossips all are met,
And in the match of Gossiping down set,
And plain Mass-Parson cutting bread for th'table
To tell how fast they talk, my tongue's not able
One tels strange news, th'other Godsworbet cries,
The third shakes her head, alack replies,
She on her Hens, this on her Ducks do talk,
On thousand things at once their tongues do walk.
So long as Cocks can tread, and Hens will lay,
Gill, and Gills Gossips will have words to say.

div.head: 572. Capa • incapabilis.
div.l: Produs in's Office seem • a simple Scribe,
Yet hath he cunning learnt to take a Bribe.

div.head: 573. A Parson and a Thief.
div.l: A lusty Parson riding on the way,
Was by a Theef commanded for to stay;
The Parson drew his sword, for well he durst,
And quickly put his foe unto the worst.
Sir (quoth the Theef) I by your habit see
You are a Church-man, and debate should flee,
You know 'tis written in the sacred word,
Iesus to Peter said, Put up thy Sword:
True (quoth the Parson) but withall then hear,
Saint Peter first had cut off Malchus ear.

div.head: 574. Similes habent labra lactucas.
div.l: Dick swash (or swaggering Dick) through Fleetstreet re • les,

With Si •
& Brettice waiting at his heels:
To one that would have tane the wall, he swore,
Zounds, dost not see my Punck and Paramour?

div.head: 575. A Souldiers jest.
div.l: One told told a Souldier sitting at the board,
(And silent) that he had an edgelesse sword;
Who straigh • reply'd, Sir, I will do my best,
To break your pate, though I ne'r break a jest.

div.head: 576. Good Advice.
div.l: One to a Serving-man this Counsell sent,
To get a Master that's intelligent;
Then if of him no wages he could get,
Yet he would understand he's in his debt.

div.head: 577. Theeves.
div.l: Two Theeves by night began a lock to pick,
One in the house awake, thus answer'd quick,
Why, how now? what a s • ir you there doe keep?
Goe, come again, we are not yet asleep.

div.head: 578. Asse.
div.l: He that loves glasse without a G.
Leave out L. and what is he?

div.head: 579. Enecat amplexu nimio, sic simia foetum.
div.l: Call Davus knave, he straight-way draws his sword,
And makes you prove as much, or eat your word.
But if you call him honest Rogue, or Jew,
He huggs you then for giving him his due.

div.head: 580. To Festus.
div.l: Festus th'art old, and yet wouldst mary'd be:
Ere thou doe so, this counsel take of me;
Look into Lillies Grammar, there thou'lt find,
Cornu a Horn, a word still Vndeclin'd.

div.head: 581. A Gentleman and his Physitian.
div.l: A Gentleman not richest in discretion,
Was alwayes sending for his own Physitian.
And on a time, he needs would of him know,
What was the cause his pulse did goe so slow?
Why (quoth the Doctor) thus it comes to passe,
T'must needs go slow, which goes upon an Asse.

div.head: 582. On Saint George.
div.l: To save a maid Saint George a Dragon slue,
Which was a noble act, if all be true;
Some say there are no Dragons; and 'tis said
There's no Saint George; pray Iove there be a maid.

div.head: 583. Similis cum simili.
div.l: Tom went to the Market, where Tom met with Tom,

Tom asked Tom, what Tom?
• ow far'st thou Tom?
Who Tom, I Tom? Is Tom (quoth Tom) you Tom;
Well God a mercy Tom; how doe you Tom?
Faith ne' • so well (quoth Tom) since Tom was Tom:
And thus was the greeting past 'twixt Tom and Tom.

div.head: 584. Ebrius oblitus.
div.l: Fucus was fox'd last night, but 'tis conceal'd,
And would not for his Office 'twere reveal'd.

div.head: 585. Dulce quod utile.
div.l: An honest Vicar riding by the way,
Not knowing better how to spend the day,
Did sing unto himself some certain Psalms;
A blind man hearing him, strait begg'd his alms;
To whom (quoth he) with coyn I cannot part,
But God thee blesse, good man with all my heart.
O, said the blind man, greater is my losse,
When such as you doe blesse without a crosse.

div.head: 586. In Dacum.
div.l: Dacus with some good colour and pretence,
For she doth lay more colours on her face,
Then ever Tully us'd his speech to grace.

div.head: 587. In Sillam.
div.l: Though I were blind, or though I never saw him,
Yet if I should Silla but talking hear;
For a right roaring Gallant I should know him,
For of a whore he talks, and still doth swear.

div.head: 588. Varietas iniquit • s.
div.l: Mat will not marry: true, 'cause ty'd to none,
He may have wenches new, when th'old are gone.

div.head: 589. Good sawce.
div.l: I went to sup with Cinna th'other night,
And to say true (for give the Devil his right)
Though scant of meat we could a morsell get,
Yet there with store of passing sawce we met.
You ask what sawce, where pittance was so small?
This, is not hunger the best sawce of all?

div.head: 590. Plagis mitior.
div.l: Katharine that grew so curst and fit for no man,
With beating soon became a Gentle-woman.

div.head: 591. To a Lawyer.
div.l: To goe to Law, I have no maw,
Although my suite be sure,
For I shall lack suits to my back,
Ere I my suit procure.

div.head: 592. Semel insanivimus.
div.l: Bedlam fate bless thee, thou wantst nought but wit,
And having gotten that, we'r freed from it;
Bridewell, I cannot any way dispraise thee,
For thou dost feed the poor, and jerk the lazie.
Newgate, of thee I cannot much complain;
For once a month, thou freest men out of pain;
But from the Counters, goodness it self defend us?
To Bedlam, Bridewell, or to Newgate send us,
For there in time, wit, work, or law sets free;
But here wit, work, nor law gets liberty.

div.head: 593. Of himselfe.
div.l: Some men there be, which say of me,
That I am not a Poet;
They say well, why? I doe not lye,
I write the truth; I know it.

div.head: 594. Vpon Annes marriage with a Lawyer.
div.l: Anne is an Angel, what if so she be?
What is an Angel, but a Lawyers fee?

div.head: 595. Aenigma.
div.l: The Devil, men say, in Devonshire dy'd of late,
But Devonshire lately liv'd in rich estate,
Till Rich his toyes did Devonshire so bewitch,
As Devonshire dy'd, and left the Devil Rich.

div.head: 596. On Cupid.
div.l: Why feign they Cupid robbed of his sight?
Can he whose seat is in the eye, want light?

div.head: 597. An Answer.
div.l: Experience shew, and reason doth decree
That he who sits in's own light cannot see.

div.head: 598. Lucus journey.
div.l: Lucus hath travel'd with an hundred pound,
Was rob'd and left well beaten, and fast bound:
But when to share their prize, they had begun,
No miracle was wrought, yet he undon.

div.head: 599. Of Nature.
div.l: Nature did well in giving poor men wit,
That fools well monifi'd may pay for it.

div.head: 600. Vilescit dives avarus.
div.l: Rufus is wondrous rich, but what of that?
He lives obscurely, like a Water-Rat.

div.head: 601. Visum ignotum.
div.l: That Crambo's wife's with child, her belly shews it:
But who was't got it? pray ask those that know it.

div.head: 602. Vpon Marriage.
div.l: Marriage as old men note, hath lik'ned bin
Unto a publick fast, or common rout,
Where those that are without would fain get in,
And those that are within would fain get out.

div.head: 603. On Annas a News-monger.
div.l: Annas hath long ears for all news to passe:
His ears must needs be long, for he's an Asse.

div.head: 604. Sir Iohn.
div.l: Now good Sir Iohn (the beggar cries) I pray
Bestow your Worship's alms on me to day,
Relieve my wants (quoth he) I am your brother,
We born are, one to help and ayd another;
My brother (qd. Sir Iohn) poor wretch • d wight,
Why, thou mistakest me, I am a Knight;
I know't, quoth he, but hark you kind Sir Iohn,
There's many a Knight kin to the begger men.

div.head: 605. Conjectus.
div.l: Conjectus says hee'l plainly prove,
Anothers Child he ought to love,
More than his Parents; which is strange,
And yet 'tis true; for I protest,
He ought to love his wife the best.

div.head: 606. Aulus.
div.l: Some (speaking in their own renown)
Say that this Book was not exactly done;
I care not much, like banquets let my Books,
Rather be pleasing to the Guests than Cooks,

div.head: 607. On envy.
div.l: Why say some, wealth brings envy, since 'tis known
Poor men have backbiters fifteen for one?

div.head: 608. Errantes errare licet.
div.l: Pandorus spends the day by telling newes,
Of such his travels as will make you muse:
Nay sir believe it, hee'l discourse at large,
How should he else be fed at others charge?

div.head: 609. To a Drunkard.
div.l: Much pratling causeth greatest thirstinesse:
Thy wife talks more then thou, why drinks she lesse.

div.head: 610. On Pru.
div.l: Pru give me leave to laugh, why shouldst thou buy
Ceruse, and Stibium, and Mercury,
And sleiking Oyles, the best that may be got,
When thy whole face Prue is not worth a groat?

div.head: 611. To Momus.
div.l: Leave for shame, Momus, leave to bark and cry,
My actions give thy slandrous tongue the lye.

div.head: 612. To Roba.
div.l: Th'art fair, 'tis true; and pretty too, I know it;
And well bred (Roba) for thy manners show it;
But whilst thou mak'st self-praise thy onely care,
Th'art neither pretty, nor well bred, nor faire.

div.head: 613. On Gallo.
div.l: Gallo's a pretty man, hath pretty hair,
A pretty hat, and cloke as one need wear;
Gallo's a Gallant, and as Gallant • use,
Can court his Mistresse, with a sprightly Muse:
Gallo's a dunce, for I supply his wit,
Which he makes nonsence by his reading it,
And 'tis no wonder, as all wise-men know,
For pretty Gallants to be dunces now.

div.head: 614. Pudor est sua damna referre.
div.l: Peter hath lost his purse, but will conceale it,
Least she that stole it, to his shame reveale it.

div.head: 615. Wheele-greace.
div.l: Men th'Axletree do Greaze, that they not screak,
But Lawyers must be Greaz'd to make them speak.

div.head: 616. Who best friend.
div.l: A Louse I say, for when a man's distrest,
And others fall off, she sticks the surest.

div.head: 617. O times and manners!
div.l: Why thus do men, manners and times accuse,
When men themselves, Manners and times abuse?
W'are bad in them, they worse by us doe grow,
Yet we complain that help to make them so.

div.head: 618. Carpe.
div.l: Of all our Modern Writers, Carpe likes none,
He loves th'old Poets that are dead and gone:
Pardon me honest Carpe, I would not be
Laid in my grave a while yet, to please thee.

div.head: 619. Non nunquam jactat egenus▪
div.l: Iack is a Gentleman I must confesse,
For there's no womans Taylor can be lesse.

div.head: 620. On Terpin.
div.l: Terpin sips wine, and gluts down meat; I think,
My Terpin drinks his meat, and eats his drink.

div.head: 621. To Phaulo.
div.l: As often (Phaulo) as thou dost amisse,
Thou hast no more excuse for it, but this,
It was against thy will; why, be it so,
Against thy will thou shalt be punisht to.

div.head: 622. Little, nothing, too much, enough.
div.l: The Poor have little, Beggars none,
The Rich too much, enough not one.

div.head: 623. On Spurco of Oxford.
div.l: Spurco from Chandler, started Aldermen,
And trust me now most Elder-like he can
Behave himself: he ne'r appears in Town,
But in his beaver, & his great fur'd gown:
His Ruffe is set, his head set in his Ruffe;
His reverend trunks become him well enough;
He wears a hoop ring on his Thumb; he has
Of Gravidud a dose full in his face:
And trick'd and trim'd, thus bravely he supposes
Himselfe another man; but men have noses;
And they that have so, maugre Spurco's skill,
Through all his robes may smell the Chandler stil.

div.head: 624. On the same.
div.l: Spurco made candles once, 'tis true enough,
Yet when I told him so, he tookt in snuffe.

div.head: 625. To Damon.
div.l: What cause, what confidence draws thee to town?
Oxford can yeeld thee nothing, get thee down;
Thou canst not turn rogue for thy private ends,
Thou canst not play the baud to please thy friends.
Thou hat'st to sell thy breath at any price,
Or flatter great ones to their prejudice.
Whence wilt thou live? (unhappy wretch!) I am
A trusty friend, thou say'st, an honest man.
That's nothing, Damon, set thy wits to school,
Not to be knave here, is to be a fool.

div.head: 626. Compotatio.
div.l: Tasso, Torquato, Trew-wit, Manlius,
Brave merry Greeks all, and ingenious:
Let us be mad a while: come here thou Squire
Of Pints and Pottles, pile us up a fire:
Then bring some sack up, quick you Canniball,
Some cleanly sack to wash our brains withall:
There is I am sure, no other Thespian spring,
No other Helicon to bathe us in.
Troul then your sack about boyes, never faile,
Commending dull men to their stands of Ale.
Tinkers wind off whole pottles in a breath,
I hate such puddle Coxcombs worse than death;
But we true bra •• of Bacchus, as our use is,
With lusty Wines will sacrifice to th'Muses.

div.head: 627. Conscientia testis.
div.l: What makes Antonia deem himselfe undone,
Being question'd since his Office first begun:
But that a Conscience tells him quae sumuntur
Tam male parta, male dilabuntur?

div.head: 628. On Terpin.
div.l: Listen who list, my Terpins nose I sing,
And much I labour to expresse the thing:
For when he snorts, it is his trumpet shrill;
It is his conduit, for 'tis running still;
His spade, his mattock, and his pruning hook▪
'Tis a convenient staple for a wall,
A handsome wedge to cleave his wood withall:
'Twill make a good ship-anchor when he lacks,
It is his gimlet, and his twibill axe.
Thy nose is proper Terpin for most uses.

div.head: 629. On Ned.
div.l: Have not I friends (quoth Ned) I dare to say,
I have not supt at home this twelve months day:
And very true it is, for sherking Ned,
At home (poor man) goes supperlesse to bed.

div.head: 630. Pecunia prevalens.
div.l: Hand off, si • sauce-box! think you Mistris Phips
Allows such lobs as you to touch her lips?
But then 'tis question'd further; if you bring her
Some legem pone, that's another thing Sir.

div.head: 631. On Love.
div.l: Where love begins, there dead they first desire:
A spark neglected, makes a mighty fire.

div.head: 632. A Herculean taske.
div.l: To curb the courage and Wives tongue keep under.
May well be call'd Hercules thirteenth wonder.

div.head: 633. On Coritia.
div.l: Coritia, when all her Table's set
With Manchet, Sauches, and good wholsome meat,
She still gives brown bread to her Son and heir,
And tells the little boy 'twill make him fair.
If so (my Love) if it be true you say,
You never ate brown bread Coritia.

div.head: 634. On Drammato.
div.l: Drammato makes new playes great store; and yet
'Tis plain, Drammato has not too much wit:
He strives too, to be pleasant, and brings in
Mimicks, and fools, to make the people grin,
I know not what the rest think, but I say,
Drammato's the best fool in every play.

div.head: 635. Taming of a Shrew.
div.l: Wouldst tame thy wife: first tame her tongue,
Who thus his wife comes o'r shall overcome.

div.head: 636. Liberty.
div.l: If he be well which hath what he can wish,
Why then doe men for stinging Serpents fish?
True liberty 'mongst vertues bears the bell;
He may live as he will, which may live well.

div.head: 637. Drammato.
div.l: Of all Drammato's playes that ere I see,
Nothing could ever make me laugh but he.

div.head: 638. On Galba.
div.l: Galba she sayes, she never tasted Man;
Galba will lye, beleeve it, now and than.

div.head: 639. To the Reader.
div.l: Such tenour I have kept here all along,
As none (I hope) can challenge me with wrong.
I injure not the least, I give no blow
To any person; he that knows not how
To scourge mans vice, unlesse he tax his name,
Makes a base Libel of an Epigram.

div.head: 640. On Formidando.
div.l: Stout Formidando walks imperiously,
With tragick Bilbo girt upon his thigh;
His roping locks, his buffe becomes him well,
And to say sooth, he looks right terrible;
He swayes the Town before him, and will slay
Whatever man he be that dares gain-say:
But Formidando pawn'd his coat last night,
And Formidando's out of money quite;
Nor oaths will passe, nor credit from henceforth,
For one poor penny, or a penny-worth:
Starv'd Creditors begin to gape; and how
To quit himself he scarcely knows; that now
Stout Formidando who was wont to daunt
Whole thousands, trembles at a Pursivant.

div.head: 641. The German-Dutch.
div.l: Death's not to be: so Seneca doth think:
But Dutchmen say 'tis death to cease to drink.

div.head: 642. Death.
div.l: What Death is, dost thou ask of me?
Till dead I doe not know;
Come to me when thou hear'st I'm dead,
Then what 'tis I shall show.

div.head: 643. On Carp and Manilla.
div.l: Manilla would with Carp be maried,
Manilla's wise I trow:
But Carp by no means will Manilla wed;
Carp's the wiser of the two.

div.head: 644. On Carp.
div.l: These are my verses which Carp reads; 'tis known;
But when Carp makes them non-sense, th'are his own.

div.head: 645. To Phaulos.
div.l: Thou art offended (Phaulos) as I hear,
Because I sometimes call thee whoremaster;
My nature's blunt, and so will ever be;
I call a spade a spade, pray pardon me.

div.head: 646. To Coracine.
div.l: What Crispulus is that in a new gown,
All trim'd with loops and buttons up and down?
That leans there on his arm in private chat
With thy young wife, what Crispulus is that?
He's Proctor of a Court, thou say'st, and does
Some businesse of my wives: thou brainlesse goose!
He does no businesse of thy wives, not he,
He does thy businesse (Coracine) for thee.

div.head: 647. On Pru.
div.l: Pru praises her complexion, nay swears
She dares compare with any of her years;
And very true it is, that Prudence sayes,
I saw not better sold these many dayes.

div.head: 648. The Parret.
div.l: If lawful't be, of things t'invent the name;
With pratling Parret, prater is the same.

div.head: 649. To Maronilla.
div.l: My Maronilla, I could easily spare
Thy hands and arms, thy shoulders and fraught haire,
I could well spare thy feet, thy legs and thighs,
Thy tongue and teeth, thy lips, cheeks, forehead, eyes:
And not to reckon each part severall,
My Maronilla I could spare thee all.

div.head: 650. Study.
div.l: Some men grow mad by studying much to know;
But who grows mad by studying good to grow?

div.head: 651. To Lionell.
div.l: Lionell shows his honourable scars,
And labours to invite me to the wars:
But I will not by no means Lionell;
I doe not love to live ill, and drink well.

div.head: 652. On Pumilio a Dwarfe.
div.l: Pumilio lying in despaire
Of further life, said, take no care
To make a Tomb for me, good folks,
I will be buried in a Box.

div.head: 653. Sharpe sauce.
div.l: Kisses and savours are sweet things,
But those have thornes, and these have stings.

div.head: 654. On Drad-nought.
div.l: Drad-nought was for his many riots laid
Ith'Counter lately, now he's wondrous staid.

div.head: 655. On Phaulos and Gellia.
div.l: Phaulos he visits, Gellia she's sick:
I am no Wizard, yet I know their trick.

div.head: 656. To his Friend.
div.l: I will not be a Foe to any,
Nor be familiar with too many;
And twice I will not love my friend,
But whom I love, I'l love to th'end.

div.head: 657. Maried Folke.
div.l: Man love thy wife; thy Husband, wife obay:
Wives are our Heart, we should be Head alway.

div.head: 658. On Pru and Galla.
div.l: Why are Pru's teeth so white, and Galla's black?
The reason is soon knowne:
Pru buyes new teeth as often as she lacks,
But Galla wears her owne.

div.head: 659. On Bombo.
div.l: When Bombo preaches (and that's thrice a year)
Nothing but wit sounds wisely in his ear.
His • ustian phrases make a noise; each strain
And swelling rapture fills his mouth again:
He's parcell-States-man, parcell-Priest, and so
If you observe, he's parcel Poet to.
Bombo thy fetches▪ and thy fangles may
Become a stage perhaps, but us'd this way,
Th'are base, and impious: let me prevail,
Talk till thy strong lines choak thee; if they fail,
Commence at Tyburn in a cart, sweet Poet,
And there a strong line will for cert • in do it.

div.head: 660. On Lulls.
div.l: Lulls swears he is all heart, but you'l suppose
By his Probassis, that he is all nose.

div.head: 661. On Paeto.
div.l: Implore the Muses, and their two top'd hill,
Still to supply fresh matter to thy quill:
Crave Phoebus aid, call Homer with the throng
Of all the Bardes, Learn'd Manes, to thy song.
I dare not (Paeto) be so bold, as do it,
Nor seem so like what I am not; a Poet.
My page invokes no deities: here love,
And indignation the best Muses prove.

div.head: 662. On the same.
div.l: My Paeto thinks he sings melodious,
And like a Swan: alas he's but a Goose.

div.head: 663. On Plutus.
div.l: Plutus, rich Plutus would have me b • stow
Some New-years gift, as other neighbours do.
Why I will send thee what thou want'st my friend;
Nothing thou want'st, and nothing I will send.

div.head: 664. To Phocion.
div.l: Thou buy'st up all that thou canst light upon,
This is the way to sell all Phocion.

div.head: 665. To Lividus.
div.l: Doe not raile basely, doe not swell with spight,
Doe not scoffe (Lividus) at what I write:
For ridden, trust me, I can hardly pace,
Nor bear thee gently like a patient Asse;
But trot amain, and if thou chance to kick,
I shall wince too, and gall thee to the quick.
Flinging full fast till I have thrown thee off,
Till I have shook thy snaffle from thy mouth;
And then in triumph (Lividus) look to't,
I spurn thy pride and follies under foot.

div.head: 666. On his Verses.
div.l: He's blind with love that likes them ev'ry one,
And he is blind with envy, that likes none.

div.head: 667. Truth.
div.l: Truth is best found out by the time and eyes;
Falshood wins credit by uncertainties.

div.head: 668. Time.
div.l: Time all consumes, both us and every thing,
We time consume; thus, both one song doe sing.

div.head: 669. To Bombo.
div.l: Most men condemn thee Bombo, when they hear
Thy high and mighty Sermons, but I swear
Thou preachest movingly; and well I may;
Thou preachest all thy Auditors away.

div.head: 670. On Plutus.
div.l: Rich Plutus needs would buy a fool, and paid
Fifty good pounds: but after triall made,
Perceiving him an understanding man,
Plutus would have his money back again.

div.head: 671. To Linus.
div.l: Thou wast my debtor when I lent the coin,
Pay me mine own, and then I wil be thine.

div.head: 672. Leven.
div.l: Love is a Leven, and a loving kiss
The leven of a loving sweet-heart is

div.head: 673. To Phaulos.
div.l: Thou ask'st me whom I think best man to be,
He's the best (Phaulos) that is least like thee.

div.head: 674. To Claudius and Linus.
div.l: Ungodly Claudius, to be good,
Wants nothing but a will:
Lewd Linus, also, wanteth nought
But power to be ill.

div.head: 675. Hot-waters.
div.l: Our trickling Tears expresse our private Love,
Love causeth tears; strange! fire should water prove.

div.head: 676. On Grotto.
div.l: Talk but of death, Grotto begins to rage,
And sweat, and swear, and yet he's blind with age.
Fie on thee Grotto, what a coil you keep?
Thy windowes they are shut, 'tis time to sleep.

div.head: 677. On Boreman.
div.l: Boreman takes tole, cheats, flatters, lyes, yet Boreman
For all the Devill helps, will be a poor man.

div.head: 678. On Crab.
div.l: Crab being caught, and in the Serjeants power,
For shame and anger look'd both red and sower.

div.head: 679. On Fargo.
div.l: Fargo by his wit and pleasing tongue,
Hath won a wench that's wondrous fair & young;
The match (he saith) is halfe concluded, he
Indeed is wondrous willing; but not she.

div.head: 680. On Richard.
div.l: Dick being drunk, in bed thought on his sin,
And that lewd course of life he lived in,
Yet long hereof for thirst, Dick could not think,
But, Drawer, cryes, now for thy smallest drink.

div.head: 681. To Spruce.
div.l: Spruce wears a Comb about him, alwayes he
To prune and smooth his pollisht haire:
The Cock's ne'r too without his Comb you see,
Spruce 'tis a Coxcomb then you weare.

div.head: 682. On This Wise age.
div.l: The Wise men were but seaven: now we scarce know
So many fooles, the world so wise doth grow.

div.head: 683. On Profuso.
div.l: Unstayd Profuso hath run thorough all,
Almost the story of the Prodigall,
Yet swears, he never with the Hoggs did dine,
That's true, for none durst trust him with their swine.

div.head: 684. On a fire in Towne.
div.l: One night through all the streets the men did cry,
Fire, fire! at which I wak't and wondred by;
Not that dry wood should burn, but because all
Did cry fire, when for water they should call.

div.head: 685. To either Vniversity.
div.l: InduDIV2ent Mother, and kind Aunt, no where
Throughout all Europe find I such a paire;
From whose faire breasts those milky rivers run,
That thousands feed, else thousands were undone.
Oh were it not that some are wean'd too young,

And some doe suck (like •
Esse •
Calves) too long.

div.head: 686. On Mounsieur Congee.
div.l: A proper handsome courtly man indeed,
And well set out with cloaths, can for a need
Discourse with legs, and quarter congees, and
Talk halfe an houre with help of foot and hand;
But when I view'd this Mounsier clean throughout,
I found that he was onely Man without.

div.head: 687. To my Reader.
div.l: My person is another as I list,
I now but act the Epigrammatist.

div.head: 688. On Physitians.
div.l: Physitians are most miserable men,
that cannot be deny'd:
For they are never truly well, but when
mo •• men are ill beside.

div.head: 689. On Puff.
div.l: Puff quarrels in his cups, and then will fight,
Is beaten sober; troth he is served right.

div.head: 690. To Flash.
div.l: Flash when thou'rt drunk, then in thy own conceit
Thou'rt valiant, wise, great, honest, rich, discreet.
Troth Flash be alwayes drunk! for well I know
When you are sober you are nothing so.

div.head: 691. Wi • tily wicked.
div.l: Good wine (they say) makes Vinegar most ta • t,
Thou, the more witty, the more wicked art.

div.head: 692. A Doctor and his Patient.
div.l: A Doctor told his patient Omphida;
The grief she felt was a Sciatica:
Which she not perfect how to nominate,
Mistaking cryes, O my Certificate!

div.head: 693. On Mounsier Powder-wig.
div.l: Oh doe but mark you crisped Sir you meet!
How like a Pageant he doth stalk the street?
See how his perfum'd head is powderd ore:
Twu'd stink else, for it wanted Salt before.

div.head: 694. To Rash.
div.l: Rash swear not! think not 'cause you swear that I
Believe you, no: he that will swear will lye.

div.head: 695. Drunk-bounty.
div.l: I'l tell you why the drunk so lavish are,
They have too much, nay more then they can bear.

div.head: 696. To Gut.
div.l: Gut eats and drinks, doth nothing else but swill,
His teeth doe grind, his mouth's the water-mill.

div.head: 697. To Simple.
div.l: Simple, you know I gave you good advice;
Little to say, that men might think you wise;
If you'l proclaim your selfe a foole you may:
I onely tell you now what others say.

div.head: 698. On Quaff.
div.l: To quench his sorrows Quaff drinks very free,
Sorrow is dry, he sayes, and so is he.

div.head: 699. To Tom Coriat.
div.l: Of all the Toms that ever yet were nam'd,
Was never Tom like as Tom Coriat fam'd.
Tom Thumb is dumb, untill the pudding creep,
In which he was intomb'd, then out doth peep.
Tom Fool may go to School, but ne'r be taught
Speak Greek, with which our Tom his tongue is • raught.
Tom Asse may passe, but for all his long ears,
No such rich Jewels as our Tom he wears.
Tom Tell-troth is but forth, but truth to tell,
Of all Toms, this Tom, bears away the bell.

div.head: 700. To a fat Vsurer.
div.l: Fat folks we say by nature are most free:
You and your purse are fat, and yet I see
Your hand and that still shut, the reasons this;
In costive flesh thy leane soule buried is.

div.head: 701. On Brisk.
div.l: Brisk brag'd of's ready wit; I tempting him
But for one Distick, did propound this theam
Nothing: I • cannot be, he wondring said
That out of nothing ought shu'd ere be made.
Dull Brisk thou ne'r couldst tune Apollo's Lyre;
A pure steeld-wit, will strike Mercuriall fire
Out of the flintiest subject: but thy head
Is all compos'd of softer mettle, lead.

div.head: 702. Semel insanivimus omnes.
div.l: Thus have I waded through a worthlesse task,
Whereto I trust there's no exception ta'n,
For meant to none, I answer such as ask,
'Tis like apparell made in Birchen-lane;
If any please to suit themselves and wear it,
The blame's not mine, but theirs that needs will bear it.

div.head: 703. On Sullen.
div.l: Sullen will eat no meat, but peevishly
Replies, I care not, nor I will not, I:
Troth I commend his abstinence, 'tis great,
When having such a stomach hee'l not eat.

div.head: 704. To Banks.
div.l: When Spendall asks to borrow, you reply,
You know not when hee'l pay you; troth nor I.

div.head: 705. To Boldface.
div.l: Boldface, I wonder at thy impudence,
That da • 'st affi • m things so against all sence:
For shame ben't impudent and foolish too!
And think all men are fools 'cause you are so.

div.head: 706. Of his Booke.
div.l: Part of the work remaines; one part is past:
And here my Ship rides, having Anchor cast.

div.head: 707. On Bearill.
div.l: Bearill because his wife is somewhat ill,
Uncertain in her health, indifferent still;
He turns her out of doors without reply:
Wondring at which, I askt the reason why?
In sicknesse and in health, sayes he, I'm bound
Onely to keep her, either weak or sound;
But now shee's neither, he replies; you'l see,
Shee'l quickly now or mend or end, sayes he.

div.head: 708. On Bib.
div.l: Wisdome doth teach us silence, now Bib is
With drink made speechlesse, is he not then wise

div.head: 709. On Silly.
div.l: Silly by chance did loose his Diary
Of wit, which he had got in company:
No marvel he now so mute and pensive sits,
How can he choose, since he hath lost his wits.

div.head: 710. Ad sesquipidales poetastros.
div.l: Hence Brauron's God to Tauriminion,
Fly thundering Bronsterops to Hippocrene,
And Mauros to Nymph-nursing Mytelene;
Grisly Megaera's ne • romantique spell
Depart to black nights Acherontick cell:
Avaunt transformed Epidaurian,
Unto th'Antipod Isles of Trabroban,
Away Cyllenius plumy-pinnion'd God,
With thy peace making wand, snakecharming rod,
And all the rest not daring look upon
Vranus blood-born brood, and fell Typhon;
Chimera's victor great Bellerophon,
Thou vanquisher of Spanish Geryon.
Stout Asdruball Sicilian Lord of yore,
Thou that destroy'dst the Caledonian bore,
Couragious conqueror of Cretes Minotaure,
Thou pride of Mermeno's cloudy Semitaure.
Perseus whose marble stone transforming shield,
Enforc'd the Whale, Andromeda to yeeld,
You Argonautes that scour'd Syndromades,
And passd the quick-sands of Symplegades,
Help Demogorgon, King of heaven and earth,
Chaos, Lucina, at Litigiums birth,
The world with child looks for delivery
Of Canibals, or Poetophagy.
A devilish brood from Ericthonius,
From Iphidemia, Nox, and Erebus,
Chide Pegasus for op'ning Helicon,
And Poets damn Pyry-Phlegeton;
Or make this monstrous birth abortive be,

Or else I will shake hands with Poetry.
—Nihil sic nisi Carmina desunt.

q.l: 'Tis wit keeps life, all else Death will down cast.

div.head: 1. On a Lyer.
div.l: GOod passenger! here lyes one here,
That living did lye every where.

div.head: 2. On a Dyer.
div.l: He lives with God none can deny,
That while he liv'd to th'world did dy.

div.head: 3. On a Iugler.
div.l: Death came to see thy tricks, and cut in twain
Thy threed, why didst not make it whole again?

div.head: 4. On Mr. Fish.
div.l: Worm's bait for Fish, but here is a great change,
Fish bait for worms, is not that very strange?

div.head: 5. On a Child.
div.l: A child and dead? alas! how could it come?
Surely thy thread of life was but a thrumme.

div.head: 6. On Mr. Do.
div.l: Do is my name, and here I lye,
My Grammar tels me, Do fit Di.

div.head: 7. On Taylor a Serjeant, kill'd by a Horse.
div.l: A Taylour is a Theef, a Sergeant is worse,
Who here lies dead, god-a-massy Horse.

div.head: 8. On Mr. Thomas Best.
div.l: With happy starres he sure is blest,
Where • 'ere he goes, that stil is Best.

div.head: 9. On Robin.
div.l: Round Robin's gone, and this grave doth inclose
The pudding of his doublet and his hose.

div.head: 10. On Bell the Tinker.
div.l: Bell though thou dy'dst decrep • t, lame, forlorn,
Thou was't a man of Mettle, I'l be sworn.

div.head: 11. On proud Tygeras.
div.l: Proud and foolish, so it comes to passe,
He liv'd a Tyger, and he dy'd an Asse.

div.head: 12. On Iohn Cofferer.
div.l: Here lyes Iohn Cofferer, and takes his rest,
Now he hath chang'd a Coffer for a Chest.

div.head: 13. On blind and deaf Dick Freeman.
div.l: Here lyes Dick Freeman,
That could not hear nor see man.

div.head: 14. On a Miller.
div.l: Death without warning was as bold as brief,
When he kil'd two in one, Miller and Thief.

div.head: 15. On a Lady.
div.l: Here lyes one dead under this marble stone,
Who when she liv'd, lay under more than one.

div.head: 16. On a Wrestler.
div.l: Death to the Wrestler gave a pretty fall,
Tript up his heels, and took no hold at all.

div.head: 17. On Iohn Death.
div.l: Here's Death interred, that liv'd by bread,
Then all should live, now Death is dead.

div.head: 18. On an Infant.
div.l: The reeling world turn'd Poet, made a Play;
I came to see's, dislik'd it, went my way.

div.head: 19. On a little but very ingenuous youth.
div.l: Grim Death perceiving, He had far out ran
The elder youth • ; mistook him for a man.

div.head: 20. On a Lady dying quickly after her Husband.
div.l: He first deceased, she a little try'd
To live without him, lik'd it not, and dy'd.

div.head: 21. On Mr. Stone.
div.l: Jerusalems curse is not fulfill'd in me,
For here a stone upon a stone you see.

div.head: 22. On Mr. Strange.
div.l: Here lies one Strange, no Pagan, Turk, nor Jew,
It's strange, but not so strange as it is true.

div.head: 23. A Forts Epitaph.
div.l: Reader, it was born, and cry'd,
Crack'd so, smelt so, and so dy'd.

div.head: 24. On Mr. Anguish a scholler.
div.l: Some doe for anguish weep, for anger I,
That ignorance should live, and art should dye.

div.head: 25. On a lovely young youth.
div.l: From thy quick death, conclude we must,
The fairest flowers are gather'd first.

div.head: 26. On Mr. Thomas A • len.
div.l: No Epitaphs need make the just man fam'd,
The good are prais'd when they are onely nam'd.

div.head: 27. On a Lady.
div.l: Finis and Bonum are converted, so,
That every good thing to an end must go.

div.head: 28. On a pious Benefactor.
div.l: The Poor, the World, the Heavens, and the Grave,
His Alms, his Praise, his Soule, and Body have.

div.head: 29. On a Poet in Prison.
div.l: Though I in prison here doe lye,
My Muse shall live altho I dye.

div.head: 30. On a poor Poet.
div.l: Here lies the Poet buried in the night,
Whose purse, men know it, was exceeding light.

div.head: 31. A man and his wife.
div.l: Viator siste, ecce miraculum!
Vir & uxor hic non ligitunt.

div.head: 32. On a Pauls-walker.
div.l: Defessus sum ambulando.

div.head: 33. On a Scrivener.
div.l: May all men by these presents testifie,
A lurching Scrivener here fast bound doth lye.

div.head: 34. On one that cheated his Father.
div.l: Here lies a man, who in a span
Of life, beyond his Father ran.

div.head: 35. On a Cut-purse.
div.l: Death hath that Cut-purse seiz'd on at Alhallows,
Who by good hap hath so escap'd the Gallows.

div.head: 36. On a young great wit.
div.l: Great wits are dangerous, for then,
